editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it was preſented, at the priuate Houſe, in the Blacke-Fryers: By His Maieſties Seruants.
LONDON, Imprinted by A. M. for Iohn Waterſon, and are to bee ſolde at the ſigne of the Crowne in Pauls Church-yard, 1630,

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE LORD WESTON, LORD HIGH TREASVRER OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
I Should doe my inclination wrong, to call this, the firſt Teſtimony of my Zeale to your Lordſhippe: For I did neuer
thinke the wonder, or the prayſe that I haue written, iuſt; vntill I found your Lordſhips Character in both: and yet the age is growne vnworthy to receiue ſuch truths; therefore, ſome were purpoſely conceal'd; and this fit eſteeme of your Lordſhip, is chiefly left to delight Poſterity. I could vrge the dignitie of Drammatick-Poems, but that were vainly to direct, rather then wooe, an acceptation. Thoſe errors, your Lordſhippes leaſure ſhall vouchſafe to reade in this Tragedy, are its originall Crimes, hauing receiu'd no examination ſince the Birth, and being aduised to correct it, by a suruay, I ſayd; I had ſtudy'd your Lordſhip,
and would not leſſen, the noble office of your Mercy. This confidence (I hope) ſhall nothing preiudice

closer.signed: Your Lordſhips humble Seruant. WILLIAM D'AVENANT.

list.head: The Perſons of this Tragedy.
list.item: COSIMO. A Courtier, and Couſen to Caſtruchio.
DORIDO. A Gentleman, Companion with both.
BORACHIO. A Ruſtick, Tennant, and Seruant to Lothario.
CORSA. Siſter to Foreſte, Wife to Lucio.

div.head: Actus Primus. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: FOREST.
sp.l: I muſt not be ſo rude as to beleeue
That you (my Lord) can your affections ſet;
Vpon a Mayde, ſo humble in her birth
As ſhe you name, for regard of honour
Doe not mock the ſiſter of your ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: This way to madneſſe leads, teach not my heart
Such modern Heraldry. Let it diſpoſe
Of charitable thoughts, with naturall eies,
Vnlimmited by cuſtomary forme,
Which gaine, and nicetie haue made an Art,
Virtue, not blood enobles vs, and ernes
Her atribute, without hereditary helpe
From anceſtors. O my deere Foreſte?
Thy ſiſter with ſuch noble wealth is fraught,
That to be couetous for her, appeares,
A holy ſinne. But thou art cruell growne
Thy memory is ſick. The old effects
That witneſſe how I loue thy learned ſoule,
Are quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Young Lord, diſclaime that thought!
Heare I Promulgate, you my Patron are;
You found me in eſtate ſo poore, ſo lowe,
That you were faine to ſtoope to lift me vp,
You are the Dukes Creature! who doates by Art,
Who in his loue, and kindneſſe, Method keepes:
He holdeth thus his Armes, in fearefull care
Not to bruſe you with his deere embracements,
And what is ſhe whoſe Virgin blood diſdaines
To quench your lawfull fire? or whom the Duk
Would not procure to climbe your Marriage be
Vpon her Knees? And ſhall I then
(Like to the treacherous Moone) ſtriue to eclip
The Sunne that giues me light? Shall I conſent
That ſhe, that tumbled in a Wombe with me,
Shall giue your Iſſue birth? The royall Duke
Would thanke me for ſuch charitie. My Lord
Though you are wiſe, you are but young.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Heart of Viper!
Sure Time hath loſt his feathers from his Heeles,
Marke how ſlow he goes? Shall I neere be olde
That my deſignes may repute haue,
And credit in the World. I doe not aske
Thy Siſter for my Whore; but for my Wife.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sir t'is already ioynd vnto my Creede▪
For I would eate your Heart, ſhould it contriue
A way in thought, how to cheate my Siſter
Of her pure Chaſtitie. I loue you ſo
That I with care ſuppoſe; She not deſerues
To be your Wife, and ſo eſteeme of her
That ſhe is much too good, to be your Whore.
In this new Argument, I am too bolde,
You know my duty well. The Dukes abroad
Though but the birth of day. Goe Sir!

div.stage: Enter Duke, Caſtruchio, Dorido, Coſimo, Page: and Followers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My glorious Boy, you are too vigilant:
The Sunne, and you, doe viſite me at once.
This courtſhip is not ſafe. You muſt not meete
Your Louer, with a Riuall, glorious
As your ſelfe. Foreſte! welcome from Genoa,
How fares our Brother Cardinall?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: In health, and eaſe. He badde me tell your Grace
It was a deed of charitie to thinke
Him worthy of this ſame great imployment.
And this letter he humbly recommends
To your peruſall.

div.stage: Duke reads the Letter to himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: How can it chooſe
But choke the very Soule, and bruſe the Heart
To thinke that ſuch a giddy Snipe: a Foole
(That meerely liues to diſparage Nature)
Should creepe to this ambitious gouernment.
Still he rules the Ruler. The Duke is Ward
Vnto a Page; whoſe Eie-browes weare more Beard,
Then doth his Chinne: And there's his Inſtrument,
A darke fellow; that with d • ſguiſed Lookes
Cou • d cheat an Hypocrite, older then Time.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: I'ue heard a better Character of both,
Such, as to the young Count, Witt, and vallour giues:
Vnto Foreſte, honeſt Spirits.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Whom Fortune do henrich, Fame doth flatter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sure this tame Prieſt will make vs all Cowards.
We muſt a truce confirme with Genoa.
Well, be it ſo. Where now (my noble Boy)
Shall I occaſion finde, to teſtifie
That you deſerue my loue, by vertue of your owne?
In ſickely times, when Warre and ciuill Spleene
Beſiege the Heart, with treacherous deſignes,
A friend ſhall find a cauſe to make him knowne,
But now in faire weather: I neede not aske
What Houell's nere?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: In this, I dare diſcredite Fate.
They are not ſo wealthy in affliction:
With ſorrow ſo well ſtor'd; as could ſuffice
To trie my ſufferance: in the behalfe
Of you my Prince, and ſtill royall Maſter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou then die for me?
Heere—make thy ſelfe a ſacrifice to Fame,
Take it: and I will be thy Chronicler.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: It were (Sir) but ingratitude in me
To l • ſſen thus, the number ſanctifide
Of your true friends. Be you pleas'd to ſheath it,
In that ſame part, which you doe moſt abhorre.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O Lucio! thou art my Earew • g now,
Creep'ſt in my eare, to feaſt vpon my Braines.
When in my priuate graue I lye inclos'd,
More ſilent then my ruin'd Fame: no tongue
Shall pay his tribute to my memory
But thine: for thou art likely to ſuruiue.
Thy yeares are few, but full of gratitude.—
Come: hye we to the Parke: The ſprightfull morne
Giues motion wings, and libertie to thoſe
Whom lameneſſe ſtakes vnto the ground.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Royall dotard, like tinder, thou doſt waſte
Thy forced fire: to giue another light
Whoſe ſawcy flame will darken thine. Monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: Why doſt thou ſpend thy gall in ſecret thus?
A pox vpon't: turne thoughts to action:
Heauen knowes, I had rather enrich my ſelfe,
Then enuy others wealth. Imploy thy brayne.
Get the Dukes fiſt to this; and thou ſhalt ſhare
Fiue hundred Crownes.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: The old buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: And not yet ſign'd: This t'is to be modeſt.
Had I had reputation in thy Creede
It had beene done long ſince. There's my agent.
Hence and prouide me thanks. Saue you Signior.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: You may with charitie.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Am I in your remembrance ſir?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Signior Caſtruchio, as I take you.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The ſame. Becauſe I neuer did deſire
To gaine by being troubleſome, I loſt
The deere benifit of the practique part.
Cuſtom's a ſutors ſafe encourager.
I the Duke haue ſeru'd, ſince I was able
To ſerue my ſelfe. Yet neuer had the luck
To get by it: and as the times promiſe,
Neuer ſhall: Vnleſſe I imitate the Crab,
And find my way (as he doth his) backwards.
That is. to make petition to the foote
That he will pleaſe t'inſtruct, and teach the head
When to comiſerate my affaire.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Signior. I neede a comment to your words.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: If you will mooue my Lord (the Count)
To get the Dukes faire hand, ſubſcribed heere;
Then ſhall I feele my ſelfe well vnderſtood.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sir my abillities are moſt pregnant
When I find I may be profitable
To any Courtiers iuſt, and modeſt ſute.
I pray what ſenſe carries the inſcription?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Only this Sir. There is an Engine made
Which ſpends its ſtrength by force of nimble wheeles,
For they once ſcrewed vp, in their returne
Will riue on Oake: but with ſuch ſubtill force
That motion giues no leaſure to impediment.
The large and ponderous Logge is ſoone conſum'd,
To ſhauings more tranſparant then a Glaſſe.
Of theſe the skillull Boxes make, Scabbards,
Sheathes, Cheaſts, and molds for childrens Cabinets.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Trust me an Engine of importance great.
But now, what would the Enginere himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Faith Signior, nought but a Monopoly
For all thoſe wares, his Engine makes.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Keepe it. Good ſir keepe it. A monopoly
Why ſir the common-wealth hath beene ſo cruſh'd,
With th'inſulting Charter of ſuch Parents,
That now the very word defiles the cauſe.
I had thought you Signior would haue ingag'd
My induſtry in ſuch a ſute as might
Noway diſparedg though it did enrich;
How euer not abuſe the publique weale.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Very good Sir. My Lord the Count, your ſelfe
(His ſeruile Inſtrument) and ſome others,
Of this new faction that now, engroſſe
All Offices, and ſend your Scoutes abroad
Intelligencers ſtrict, that bring you home
The number, and the rate of what your ſelues,
Or others in the darke can put to ſale.
Nature hath not altered yet: the firſt
And antick method to preſerue our breaths.
We muſt eate bread if we intend to liue;
Which how to get (vnleſſe this humble way
That you deride) In troth I cannot tell.
It makes me mad to thinke you ſhould expoſe
Vs Men of Heart, to thoſe faſtidious helpes
That ſcape your owne acceptance. Your wide Threats,
That ſoone will ſwallow any thing which fills
Although it nouriſh not. A pox vpon you all!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I did expect you would begin to rayle.
Good troubled Soule! I knew you well before.
You are the only Man, whoſe wealthy Muſe
Doth furniſh all the Fidlers in the State
With d • ſp'rate Ballads, and inuectiue Songs.
Libells of ſuch weake fa • cy and compoſure
That we doe all eſteeme it greater wrong
T'haue our Names extant in ſuch paltery Ryme
Then in the ſlanderous ſence.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Very well Sir!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: You, you muſt be a Satyriſt forſooth,
Calumniate by inſtinct and inſpiration.
As if iuſt Heauen would borrow Gall of you,
Wherewith to write our faults. (O ſtrict account!)
Your Gall, which in the Pen ſo ouerflowes,
That ſtill it blots, where in inſcribs.
You imitate the propertie of Doggs,
Who barke and ſnarle moſt at him they know not
For elſe among all thoſe you ſcandalize
Why nam'd you me? (almoſt a ſtranger to your Eye)
My Anceſtors that built no Monument
For their fames to dwell in; You alſo bring
Into the knowledge of the criticke World.
Why I could neuer ſee thee yet but dru • ke:
Which makes thy Verſes reele and ſtagger ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Come ſir! We may exchange one thruſt vnſeene.
They draw fight, cloſe, For ſtings down Caſ & diſarmes him.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: A prety Curr! dare it bite as well as barke!
How now ſir, your Mathematicall thruſts!
Then haue at ye—Yeeld me thy Sword, or elſe thou dy'ſt.
I haue no ioy to ſet a • liberty
A Soule ſo vnprepar'd. And as thou art
My Enemy, I take a full reuenge,
By ſuffering thy corrupted blood to dwell.
And taint within th • vaines. W'are diſcouered—
Take thy ſword Now get thee home and rayle vpon't,
Becauſe t'would fight no better.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Yet we may meete i'th' darke. You haue a throat
And there are Kniues in Italy.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: A good day attend my ghoſtly Father!
Doth this your tariance heere diſcouer ought,
You would with me?

sp.speaker: Monke.
sp.l: Your leaſure ſhall produce my vtterance.
O Sonne, your fame is of complexion cleere,
Such as enſnares the virtuous Eye, to loue
And adoration. Such as would procure
All the skilfull Angels ſutors to her,
And ſuch as ſerues for my encouragement
For I no letters haue from Noble friends,
Which a requitall from themſelues inuite,
By Courtſhip bold, and troubleſome to others,
Noram I with that wicked mettall ſtor'd,
That rules the mighty, and betrayes the minde
To toyle in a deſigne, which angers Heauen,
And makes the Deuill bluſh. But yet (deere Sonne)
I haue a ſuite to thee.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Which I deſire to know.

sp.speaker: Monke,
sp.l: In the ancient Covent of S. Auſtine
There is a holy brother lately dead,
Whoſe place if you will but confirme on me
By the Dukes letter to the brother-hood,
Then ſhall I better leaſure haue to pray
For you my Patron.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Alas my Father!
The times are more obſeruant to your Tribe.
It is the method now that your deſerts
Need not to vſher but ſucceed reward.
The Treatiſe (written lately) to confute,
The deſperate ſect in Mantua, calls it you
The Author?

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.l: It knowes no other.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: There your preferment ſafely taketh roote.
Beleeue me (ghoſtly Father) I will chooſe
The fitteſt time to woke in your behalfe.

sp.speaker: Monke.
sp.l: Heauen proſper your deſignes.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: What throngs of great impediments beſiege
The vertuous minde? ſo thick in multitude,
They ioſtle one another as they come.
Hath Vice a charter got, that none muſt riſe
But ſuch, who of the Deuils faction are?
The way to honour is not euermore
The way to Hell: a vertuous Man may climbe.
Let the flatterer ſell his Lies, elſe where
It is vnthrifty merchandize to change
My gold for breath. Of all Antagoniſts
Moſt charitie I finde in enuious men.
For they doe ſooner hurt themſelues, then hurt
Or me, or him, that rays'd me vp.
An enuious man is made of thoughts.
To ruminate much doth melt the braine,
And make the heart grow leane. Such men as theſe:
That in oppoſing waſte their proper ſtrengths:
That ſacrifice themſelues in ſilly hope,
To butcher vs; ſaue Reuenge a labour,
And dye to make experiment of Wrath.
Let Fame diſcourſe aloud vntill ſhe want
An Antidote: I am not ſcar'd with noyſe.
Heere I diſmiſſe my feares. If I can ſwell
(Vnpoyſon'd by thoſe helpes, which Heauen forbids)
Fond loue of eaſe, ſhall neere my ſoule dehort:
Maugre all flattery, enuy, or report.

div.l: O good your Grace heare vs, heare the complaints
Of vs poore Men: O heare vs! we are all
Vndone! Good your Honour heare vs.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Death encounter 'em! Lucio ſhut the doore!
Tis the plague of greatneſſe, the curſe
Of pompe, that in our darkeſt priuacie, wee muſt
Euen publique be to euery Mans affaires.
How now! All theſe ſawcy Troopes of brawling
Sutors, attend on you my glorious Boy.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: It is their humble skill not to arriue
Before your Grace, but by an Aduocate
A Mediatour bleſſed in your Eies.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How apt am I to loue! yet now obſerue
Vnkindneſſe in my care, and bitterneſſe
In Phyſicke. I ſtudy how to make thee leſſe
That I may make thee more and more my owne.
Office and Dignity are Enemies
To health, and eaſe. Reſpect growes tedious
Obſeruance troubleſome, where ti's moſt due.
He that giues his Soule no more imployment
Then what's her owne: may ſleepe within a Drumme.
While buſie Hearts, that loue to vndertake
Beyond their reach of yeeres: are faine to vſe
Drowſie potions: yet watch the Winter night
With more diſtinction then the Pariſh Clocke.
Could'ſt thou reſigne thy titles and thy cares
To make me yet more capable of ſtill
Enioying thee?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: My zeale vnto my ſelfe forbids my ſpeech.
Since if I make reply to this, I but
Diſparedge duty, and conſume my breath.
Where • ight is young, and cleere, there Spectacles
Are troubleſome; and rather hide, then ſhew
The obiect. The moſt deuout obedience
Which I ſhall euer owe vnto your Grace
Becomes my heart, much better then my tongue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But yet obſerue (my Lucio)
Th'vnkind tricks of Nature: how we are fool'd
By a religious conſtancy in Loue.
A Princes hate doth ruine where it falls:
But his affection warmeth where it ſhines
Vntill it kindle fire to ſcorch himſelfe.
If we are ſubiect to the ſinne of Heauen,
(Too much charitie) extreamity of loue:
Let there be mercy ſhewen in puniſhment.
Why is the corrupted vſe of Royall loue
Imputed to our charge, to our Audit layd?
We that with all thoſe Organs furniſh'd are
All thoſe faculties naturall in Men:
Yet limitted in vſe of each: preſcrib'd
Our conuerſation, by a ſawcy forme
Of State. How can we chooſe (by this reſtraint)
But ſtruggle more for liberty? make choiſe
Of ſome one Eare; wherein to empty out our Soules,
When they are full of buſie thoughts; of plotts
Abortiue, crude, and thinne. T'is cheape, and baſe
For Maieſtie not to be ſingular
In all effects. O then, if I muſt giue my heart
To the command of one: ſend him (ſweete Heauen!)
A modeſt appetite: teach him to know
The ſtomacke ſooner ſurfeits with too much,
Then ſtarues for lacke of that ſupply
Which couetous Ambition calleth want.
For when my Friend beggs, my bounty then
Concludes to make me poore before that he
Shall ſo vnthrifty be of breath to aske in vaine.
Diſtraction! tameneſſe! O my Lucio.
How canſt thou conſter this. After I haue chid
I ſeeme to flatter thee.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: My gracious Lord!—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Peace—
I will no more imploy my memory
Thus to diſcourage thine. Where's Foreſte!
T'is fit he know you are not vigilant
In his behalfe. Farelo de Sforza
(My old Secretary) is newly dead:
The place is his. I ſhall expect no thankes
From you, nor yet from him:
My bounty is requited in her choice.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Your Grace will bring vs both within the reach
Of publique enuy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou now would'ſt certifie,
His birth obſcure and baſe diſcourageth
Such earneſt helpe to his ſo great promotion.
Not a iot: Know my Boy! t'is the vulgar,
Not the Royall trade to patch vp things:
Or ſeeke to mend what was before of qualitie
Perfect enough it ſelfe. To make a Man
Of nothing: why this ſame creation
Enclines a little neere Diuinitie.
Neere the old performance; which from Chaos
Drew this multitude of ſubtill formes.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Since you (the royall maker) doe commend
The mettall, and your workemanſhippe; it ſhewes
There's little skill in thoſe which enuy him.
Foreſte is your Creature. Many times
I doe acquaint him what the generall voyce
Doth vrge in his diſgrace. He laughs it out
And ſweares he would not looſe that priuiledge
Which Nature gaue him by her kinde miſtake
In his natiuitie, for the Seas worth.
As if from's Iſſue, he could ne're deſerue.
A •• nument, v • leſſe himſelfe doe hewe
The ſtones whereof t'is built: vnleſſe he raiſe
His Monument on a Wart; his dignitie
On pouertie obſcure and baſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We doe aff • ct his thoughts Such induſtry
Proclaimes him fit for high deſignes: Some Men
Attend the talking Drumme, and riddle out
Their liues on Earth; with Madneſſe Sophiſtry:
Calling their loſſe, their gaine, danger, delight.
Some men conuerſe with Bookes, and melt the braine
In ſull • n ſtudy how to vindicate
The liberall Arts. Thoſe looſe formalitie,
Then grow Methodicall; and dy i'th' darke.
Some practiſe rules of State, and ſuffer much
For Honors ſake: nay tread vpon themſelues
At firſt; to reach the higher. Some purſue
The Plough; and in their wholeſome ſweat doe ſwimme.
And ſome that furniſh'd are with nimbler ſoules,
Imploy their times in wanton exerciſe;
Maſques and Reuells: the complements of Loue,
And Loue I finde the eaſieſt vanity.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: O gentle Corſa! make it ſo with me,
Faine would I (if I durſt) reueale to him
The heate of my affection, and where t'is fix'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hearke: ſure the gallery doore is left vnlockt.
Are we debard all place of priuacie?
Nature in vs hath loſt her vulgar right.
A loude, bawling ſutor; doth not waken
Charitie, but deafen her.
A ſhame vpon 'em all? In Lucio.

div.stage: Enter Sutors at the other doore.
div.l: 1. Heauen bleſſe his Grace!
2. Amen: and my Lord the Count's good Honor.
3. Friend▪ went the Duke this way?
2. Heere. This way.
3. Pray ſhew me him: they call Signior Lucio
2. The Count. Come, I'le ſhew you him.
1. Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: Doſt heere? Coſimo.

sp.speaker: Cosi.
sp.l: What ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I prethee ſtay, why ſlip but heere aſid •
And thou ſhalt ſee the moſt reſplendent Fopp,
That euer did diſcredit Nature. Sigmor.
Lothario; a Countrey Gentleman
But now the Court Baboone: who perſwades himſelfe,
(Out of a new kinde of madneſſe) to be
The Dukes fauorite. He comes. Th'other is
A bundle of Prouerbs: whom he ſeduc'd
From the Plough; to ſerue him for Preferment.

sp.speaker: Lotha.
sp.l: Borachio.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Suruay my garments round, and then declare If I haue hit it?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You haue ſir: but not the marke.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: What marke? thou bold Pariſhioner of Hell.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why Sir, the marke I aime at: Preferment.
After a ſtorme, comes a calme: the harder
You blow, the ſooner your Cheekes will ake: and he
That cares for your anger, may haue more of't
When he liſt, for my part, I know my Mother.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: The froward Siſters haue conſpir'd Slaue! Dog
Wilt thou neuer leaue this immenſe folly?
Can nothing ſerue theſe dull Lippes but Prouerbs?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir, I know none of your Prouerbs. Firſt come,
Firſt ſeru'd. Theſe words that are neereſt the tongue,
Haue opportunitie ſooneſt to leaue
The mouth.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Is it then decreed, I muſt grow mad?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I'le be no more flow • ed, nor bruſ'd, not I
What need my Lord, be beholding to me
For's mirth; when he may laugh at's owne folly?
Beſides though motion and exerciſe
Be good for groſſe bodies; therefore, muſt they
Of the Guard, pitch me vp and downe like a barre?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Sa, ſa, ſa, A mutinie in Heauen!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: If there be; You are not likely to come
Thither to appeaſe it, firſt end this quarrell
Vpon earth, I haue ſeru'd you this ſixe Moneths,
In hope of an Office; and am no more
An Officer then ſhe that bore me.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Alas poore foole!
I pitty thee. Thou wilt beleeue nothing
But that which may be ſeene or vnderſtood.
I ſay thou art an Officer. Or if thou art not
Thou ſhalt be; which is better: for that ſame
Which we now enioy is in ſome danger
To be loſt: but that which we neuer had
Cannot be loſt before we haue it.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: O rare concluſion:

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Beſides. Looke heere and then reioyce, Is the Count
(Whom they call my Riuall ith' Dukes fauour)
Is he (I ſay) accoutred like to me?
Why his ſleeues ſit like ſtockins on his Armes.
His Breeches are like two Clokebags, halfe ſowde
Together in the Twiſt: and his other
Garments ſhew like Playſters on him. Follow.
And make thy fortune fat.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Well. He that ſtill expects, but tires his hope,
What One cannot, another can: t'is ſo
With dayes and houres too. And for my part
Let the Glaſſe runne out.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: His Man's as full of Prouerbs
As a Conſtable: he coyns 'em himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And ſuch another Heade-peece fill'd with Whay
As is the Maſter heere, the Sunne nere ſaw.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: He walkes like a Zealand-ſtorke.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But ſure the Duke
Enables error in their fancy, by ſome
Behauiour equiualent to what
The Maſter, and the Man expect: for elſe
Folly cannot be ſo ſickely-Eied; but time
Will giue it ſtrength to know it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: Why ſir; this dignifies the Ieaſt. They ſcarce
Ere ſaw the Duke: and are leſſe knowne
Vnto the world. His Grace well apprehends,
Theſe voluntary miſtakes of Nature,
In preſeruation of their intellects,
Are fitter ſubiects for accidentall mirth,
Then a Comicall continuance. It is
A leuitie too humble in a Prince
To heede ſuch trifles.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Nay—Prethee lead the way▪

sp.speaker: FORES.
sp.l: I cannot tell, why thou (my Girle) ſhould'ſt ioy
In my aduancement thus. Honour, and place
Bring ſullen thoughts with them: buſineſſe of ſuch
A ragged qualitie, as takes away
The amorous garbe: thoſe ſoft wanton touches,
Wherewith the youthfull flatterer betrayes
The weaker ſide to action: whoſe effects
More weakeneſſe brings. I ſhall no leaſure haue
To comfort thee with ſmiles: when t'is aſsign'd
That I muſt venture for a Boy: t'will be
In haſte. My buſineſſe will not ſuffer me
To ſtay, and make a prologue to the acte,
To kiſſe, or ſimper inuitation.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: It is not fit I apprehend you now,
But I wiſh that you would know; My duty
Is ſo well preſeru'd from all corruption:
Which either youth: or fowle example might
Produce: that it in plores for •• fferance,
To certefie the world how ſtrong it is.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: I was aſſur'd before. This is the time,
In which I ſhall oblige poſteritie
Or fall (my wench) by flattering error.
Haſt thou to my ſiſter counſaile giuen?
Inſtructions ſafe! whereby her actions
May warrant her promotion well deſeru'd.

sp.speaker: Luin,
sp.l: It was my tongues laſt imployment.

sp.speaker: Foreſ
sp.l: I would haue her weare her growing fortunes,
In a handſome faſhion: Doe but obſerue
The vnpolliſh'd garbe of Citty dames: of thoſe
Whom • athers purſe-ſtrings hoyfe vp to honor.
How they doe ſucke their Chinnes into their Neckes.
Simper with vnskilfull leuetie: and trip
On their wanton Toes; like Kibe • heel'd-Fayries.
The Deuils damme ſhewes like a veſtall Nunne
To them: more powerfull in humilitie.
Inſtruct my Siſter, gentle wife.—

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: I ſhall be earneſt to my vtmoſt skill.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: My Lord is come, where's my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.l: VVith the Horentine: who inſtructeth her▪ in muſicke.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Signior Foreſte,
You ſee my loue is rude, and bolde. • am
The vſher to my owne entrance.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: My good Lord, The prouerbe will perſwade you:
To be bold, with wha • s your owne.
Your title's ſtrong, bo •• to the houſe, and me.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: I am in debt for both. wilt thou not childe.
To ſee my heart aſſume this libertie.
Vpon my Tongue: before it rightly knowes!
Thy ſiſters heart:
The Duke conſent, as yet vnasked too: h • arke?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Ceaſe that noyſe, tis troubleſome:

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: How Foreſt? Haſt thou eares? and wilt thou •
〈◊〉 ſuch hopefull harmony, 〈…〉
Thy thriſt vnnaturall, wilt thou forbid
Thy friend to ſhare in what is good, ſweet tongue
And hand, perſiſt in what your kindneſſe profferd.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Obey him, if the muſick not deſerue
Your ſtrict attention: You muſt blame your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Shew me the way Foreſte.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Whither ſir?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: My heart is ſtolne out of my eare; let me
But know the thiefe, and Ile forgiue the robbery.
Speake; who iſt that, with a voyce ſo amorous
And ſhrill, confounds the others hollow organ?
Still ſo reſeru'd, and vnto me.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Why then looke there, the voyce was hers, goe ſir
And take what elſe you would enforce from my poſſeſsion.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Is this that child of Orpheus? how? kneele to me?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Stay Sir—If ſhe conſent but to abuſe
The propertie of motion in ſuch kinde
As may exalt her perſon but on ſuch
Aboue this height: I am her enemy
For euermore. Conſider what you doe.
She brings no portion but humilitie,
If her firſt payment faile: who dares aſſure
The future debt? Pray looke into her lappe:
You'le finde ſhe comes not from the Eaſt enrich'd
With Diamonds, bright wealth: whoſe wanton worth
Vnskilfull fancy priſes not from vſe
But from the idolatrous doting of the eie.
Her chaſte obedience is all her dowrie.
O bitter ſpeech! it cuts my very ſoule
To thinke that fortune ſhould create vs two
Meere patterns of your charitie.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Dare you authorize this Idolatry?
Then I'le kneele too.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: And I,
Will ioyne to make th'offence ſeeme virtuous.
Now enterchange your ſoules. Where paſsion is
So fond, it cannot well be counterfeit.
Each vnbuſied Angel, heare me ſpeake!
O ſend, ſend downe vnto this youthfull paire
Celeſtiall heate. Such ſerious loue as makes
A buſineſſe of delight; Inſtruct her ſoule
To practiſe duty in the humble ſtraine.
And furniſh him with an acceptance prompt.
Make her fruitfull as the Vine; which growes
Crooked with the weight of its owne encreaſe.
So bleſſed in their Iſſue, that when time
Shall thinke them fit to taſte the priuiledge
Of Death: they ſhall not need a Monument
Yet dwell as chiefe i'th' memory of Fame.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Such is my prayer too. O Foreſte!
Exceſsiue ioy diſturbs my vtterance.
My words are parted on any tongue. O ſpeake!
Thou know'ſt my heart! Tell her, there may lie hope,
I ſhall deſerue thoſe Teares that ſhew like deaw
Vpon the Morning cheeke. Intreat her, that
My yeeres may not diſgrace my loue. Though I
Am young, I cannot counterfeit,
I euer ſpeake my thoughts. I am o'recome.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Alas ſir, ſo am I, There needs no Art,
To helpe beliefe, where no ſuſpition is.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Now; I'le leaue you to your ſelues.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I'ue much to promiſe in my owne behalfe:
Of my future loue, and humble duty
To you my deereſt Lord. Time layes his hand
On Pyramides of Braſſe, and ruines quite
What all the fond Artificers did thinke
Immortall workemanſhip. He ſends his wormes
To Bookes, to old Records: and they deuoure
Th inſcription. He loues Ingratitude,
For he deſtro • d the memory of Man:
But I ſhall neere forget on what ſtrange termes
You ta •• me to your bed.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Excellent wretch! I am vndone with ioy
I will not blame the Coward to feare death,
Since the world containes ſuch ioy as this.
Why doe you weepe Lady? can you ſuppoſe
Foreſte would conſent to what is done,
Vnleſſe he knew there were no danger in't?
Sure his Mother was a Sibyll; he ſees
With a prophetique aime; the end of his
Deſignes; before they come to action.
He is too wiſe to erre. Why weepe you then?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: It is a folly in my Eies.
I know not why they weepe: vnleſſe they weepe
Becauſe they now haue loſt their libertie;
Heeretofore each man, which chance preſented,
Was to them a lawfull obiect: but now,
They are to looke on none but you.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Marke then the bondage I impoſe on mine,
My poore eies haue no obiect, but your face:
Of which I will depriue them thus—
sp.stage: Couers her face with her white Vaile.
sp.l: Shroude thee in thy veſtall ornaments.
Creepe, creepe, my glorious Sunne, behind a cloud.
For els my eies, will ſu • feit with delight.
I neuer felt true ioy till now. Me thinks
A briske alacritie, a nimble fire,
Con • ayes me ſtrangely from my fleſh.
Not the Cannons, Iron-entraile, when wrapp'd
Within a ſwarthy caſe of troubled Aire,
Could • quall me in emphaſis of Motion.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Though Mo • eſt would ſuffer me to boaſt,
Yet t'were not in the power of breath, to make
My ioy ſo knowne, as i • is felt.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Come then (my deare Corſa) the Prieſt attends
Within; the world wants Men; and Hymen is
A nimble God. When all is paſt preuention
The Duke ſhall know my choice.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: This diſgrace, makes thy Couſen boyle his heart
In his owne blood.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: He hath writ a moſt peſtilent Libell
Which muſt be ſung all about the city,
By one he calls his Daw; A tall, bigg, fellow.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know him. He ſings like Phalaris Bull.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I ſuppoſd at firſt, he would haue ſent him
A Challenge.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But that's contingent now: Foreſte
Being made Secretary of State.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I'haue heard o'th' new edict, which inſtitutes
A miſterious toy, • 'th' H • tband, for thoſe
Of the faction.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why about two dayes ſince: one of the ſect
Sent me a Challenge. Becauſe my ſiſter
Drunke his Lords health, with her Quoife on. Each houre
Theſe giddy Participles doe imbarque
Themſelues for Duels. The one is a kinne
To my honorable Lady. Ih'other
To my very good Lord.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: There comes my Couſen, chawing his leane heart.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good morrow to the Court Satyriſt.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The world is altred Dorido, Foreſte
Is ſtepp'd beyond my reach: we cannot meete
In Duell: The Heralds ſtand betweene.
But my ſine Thruſh, can ſing you a new Lybell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: We ſhall haue your Thruſh, in a Cage ſhortly.
Remember, who you deale withall.

sp.speaker: Caſt,
sp.l: Hang him, d • ll, open ſlaue, His thoughts may be
Diſcernd, through the ſhauing of a deale bo • d.
I'le ſift and winnow him, in an old hat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Prethee (ſweete Caſtruchio) leaue thy barkeing.
'Twill bet treaſon ſhortly for any man,
To carry eares, within three, miles of thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why Signior, what Faction are you of:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not of your faction (Sir) if none returne
Vnto the priſon for your libelling.
You remember your Vices-ſtrip'd, and whip'd.
Your trimme Eclogues, the fulſome Satyr too,
Written to his Grace. Wherein you flatter,
Whine, and damne your ſelfe to get a pardon
For what ſeemes there a reſolute offence.
Satyrs, are more vſefull, now then euer.
Nor grieues it me to ſee the humour vs'd,
But thus abus'd. To ſee a Bard ſtill reach
At ho • Bayes, Paſsion o'me! I'le tell thee.
Thy R • mes i • clude not ſo much Braines, as would
Suffice to fill a Cherry-ſtone.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Yo'ld faine make me angry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I, with thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And then thou ſpend'ſt thy Gall, with more iuſtice,
Then when, thou rayl'ſt againſt Foreſte.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Cry you mercy (precious Cox) Hath Foreſte,
So great a ſhare in your tongue too? Sympathy
Is corupted. Behold ſociety
Amongſt the wicked: whilſt a vertuous man,
Is left alone to reſiſt his bad fate.
Let him chide the fulſome Age, raile againſt
The Times, aloude; though in a Vault: or'tweene
Two Hills. He ſhall find no zealous ecchoe,
To ſecond his bold Language. When I dye,
I dye a Martyr to the Common-weale.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Dull Caytife, leaue theſe abortiue Prouects,
And talke in the neweſt faſhion. I'le haue
My very Dugge barke i'th' Courtly garbe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Steppe aſide. They are as mad as thy Couſen.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: The excrements and meere defects of nature,
ſhall be reduc'd to Ornaments in me.
I'le feed vpon the tongues of Nightingales,
For ſo each fart I let, will be a Song—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: For the Peripateticks being Butchers
Heere in Sienna:—

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: A Pallas hewne in an intire Carbuncle.
Encircled with a More that flowes with Lhaſis—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Derin'd their Angury from the warme Entrailes
Of a Calfe.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir. Theſe are ſome of thoſe, that laugh'd at yee
In the preſence.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: At me? thou lyeſt. They laugh'd at thee.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Why then the Deuill, will ne're giue a Ma •
Leaſure, to beleeue a trueth.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Seignior Lothario, the great Minion
To our Duke: I greet your health, with all ioy.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And I with all humility.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: And I with all celerity.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Hearke! thou dull Sinner. Is this reall? hah?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Sir, let him, that hath a heart of his owne
Thinke what he liſt.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Doe they adore, or floute me now?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: All is witc • craft. know when the Moone winks
There's ſomething in' • , beſides an ecclips.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Miſcreant: What ſuſpitious follys
Doſt thou creat within that Wolden-skull?
And with what Heathen-phraſe vtter'd? Know Dogg,
If I imploy my wrath—

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Allas ſir l'ue more faults then misbeliefe.
Therefore giue me your bleſ • ing, and let me
Goe home in peace. T'is true, wh • n the skie falls
We ſhall haue Larkes. But let weaker ſtomachs,
Ex • ect ſuch curious meate. I can eate
Oates, and Garlick, vnder my owne Roofe.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: How? will Borachio leaue the Court?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What accident of dire portent is fallne?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: G • ntlemen applaude my patience: Becauſe,
He cannot furniſh me with wholeſome Sutes,
He doubts my power to get 'em granted.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why we, will furniſh him with Sutes.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: But wont yee floute, and play the knaue with one?

sp.speaker: Caſt
sp.l: How (Knaue!) was that the word?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Interpret the word, as your ſelfe ſhall pleaſe.
I ſcorne to be your Dictionary.
Marry come vp: Are your eares ſo tender?
I hope I'm a Man, although a ſinner.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Vſe no choller Amorous childe. But if
Thou wanteſt ſutes, thy Lord being neere the Duke,
May furniſh thee with—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Or me thinks thou would'ſt become a knighthood
Get him to begg it for thee.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: No, no, Hot words make but warme aire, A figg
For a Knight-errant; that hath a ſtile, and nere a hedge.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: Then get a Patent to ſuruay Brine-pits.
Or elſe for caſting Ordinance in Lome.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Or elſe ſearch Saint Peters patrimony,
Lay Prebendrys are good, and Symony
Is an old Paradox.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Holde, holde
Enough ſufficeth all women but whores.
He that expects the Morning lengthens the Night
Therefore ſtraitway let my Lord get the Duke
To ſigne theſe Patents: which done
I'le returne to the wife of my bowels,
And dye for ioy.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why this, is fit, and requiſite.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: If Signior Lothario doe conſent.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: It is decreed.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Who would haſten Time, when we may be old
Too ſoone. Let me take downe a Cuſhion, and pray.
For I ſhall haue more dignitie then will ſuffice
To damne a Monke.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Who could periſh in a better cauſe?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Why, can I helpe it? If a man be borne
To Offices. Or as my Maſter ſayd,
Predeſtinate in the wombe of greatneſſe.
Tis not our faults. Each man obayes his Starre,
In ſpight of his Teeth,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: All this is Alcaron.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: One thing grieues me. I'ue a badd memory
Already, and now t'will be made worſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: How can preferment hurt thy memory?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: O Sir! preferment makes a man forget
His deereſt friends; nay his kindred too.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Looke, Thy Maſter's building more Caſtles, in the Aire.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: He has intelligence from Spaine, and fortefies,
To no purpoſe gainſt the next Spring.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: All offices ſhall be ſold i'th' darke—

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: How! Grow not old in anothers garment,
Sell what's your owne, Some of thoſe offices
Are mine by promiſe.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Still, croſſe to my deſignes. Ile ſtretch your Sinws •

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hold! Signior Lothario, hold! Mercy
Becomes the powerfull,

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Let the Deuill take the Knighthood, and make
His Damme a Lady. I'le not be his Aſſe,
sp.stage: Exit Bor. Loth. running after him.
sp.l: That ſeru'd for blowes, and Prouander.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lets relieue Borachio, or all our Comick Scenes
Are at an end.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Foreſte

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are yet our Letters to his Holineſſe
Diſpatch'd?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: They are ſo pleaſe your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Did the French-Embaſſador make ſome ſhew
Of diſcontent at his departure hence?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Both in his words and lookes: for when he heard
Th' Engliſh-Leiger had oppos'd his Treaty
Concerning traſſique with the Florentine,
His anger ſtraight diſmiſſed the Argument,
And ſeiz'd vpon the Nation, nay rayl'd
Againſt the Leiger too, whoſe oppoſition,
Might be chidden as too nice a Virtue,
But could not be accuſed as a vice,
Tis knowne indeed the French doe take a prides,
In the emphaſis of ſudden anger,
As if alacritie in ill did make,
The fault looke handſomely, and dulneſſe adde
Deformitie to ſinne.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Tis faithfully obſeru'd.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Swell'd with vncharitable pride: ſuch as
Admits no ſtile of Neighbour; as if growne
Aboue the vſe of friendſhippe. They ſeeme to call
Thoſe mighty Ilanders neereſt their ſoyle,
Poore borderers to their Continent. Such,
Whoſe thinne numbers, haue in bloudy battaile,
Made their multitudes their impediments,
Worne their Enſignes, inſtead of gaudy Skarfes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The chance of war,
Admitteth many times of Miracles,
Euen ſuch, as doe diſcredit Hiſtory,
High-prouidence confers the conqueſt there,
Where probability conferd the loſſe.
And this is done, that we may attribute
The prayſe to him that gaue the victory,
Not to them that got it. Obſerue beſides,
That when the weake doe ouercome: the ſtrong,
Doe leaue that ſtaine, for their Poſteritie
To wipe away: which is already done;
The French, haue fiery ni • ble ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Your Grace deales iuſtly in your praiſe. They (haue
Spirits: but they all are vſeleſſe made,
By forward and affectate violence.
He that ſpends his fury, and his ſtrength
I'th' firſt charge, muſt not hope to make's retreate,
So nobly, as the modeſt Combarant,
Whoſe onſet ſlowly mooues: as carefull not
T'outride his skill. Their vallour is t'attempt.
Not to performe. T'is a giddy Nation;
And neuer ſerious but in trifles.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou doeſt miſtake in naturall effects,
Where Fanc • is ſo rich, the incident
To ſ • me u • -expence. Theſe 〈◊〉
Divulge the wealth o •• h' Braine. •• uite that is ripe
Is prone to fall, or to 〈◊〉 ſelfe.
〈◊〉 to the •• e of •• archies:
Th • y now are full • ripe: they reach
The height, and 〈◊〉 of mortall • aeuleies.
Nature 〈◊〉 them doth ſtand vpon the verge
Of her 〈◊〉 y • uth The Engliſh want
Three • u • dred y • eres of that perfection.
And as the Moo • e ner'e changes but i'th'full
Euen ſo the mighty Nations of the Earth,
Change in their greateſt glory. Firſt their ſtrict
And rugged d • ſcipline, to vaine delights.
Their ſolemne Marches next to wanton • igs.
Their Battailes fierce to Duells ſpleenatiue,
Or witty quarrels of the Penne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Heere may my knees take root: whilſt I doe grow
A liuing Statue of true obedience,
Or let my royall Maſter grant his pardon.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sure we may truſt, the iudgement of our eies,
Thou doſt not looke as if thou could'ſt commit
A ſinne ſo horrid, ſo vgly as can fright
Our mercy from vs. Riſe, we pardon thee.
Now let vs know thy crime.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: It is no crime
Vnleſſe againſt that great prerogatiue
Youre eare hath ouerrune. Perhaps my Heart,
Hath made eſcape through theſe fonde Eies. And I
(I'th' raſh diſcretion of my youthfull blood)
Confin'd my ſelfe in Matrimoniall bonds.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hah! maried? ſpeake ſuddenly, to whom?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Io my Siſter. Sir pardon the permiſsion,
Or frowne, and leaue your creature more obſcure
Then when you own'd him firſt. Now is the time
To ſhew your charity Diuine. Preſerue
What you haue made.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Foreſte this is ill.
What confederate with vngouern'd youth?
But 〈◊〉 , we pardon you. Where's the Lady?
Rare beauty!—
You haue our pardon, and our fauour too.
I thus inuite more knowledge of your worth.
Beleeue me Lady: you haue a feature
That • ould b • tray a more experienc'd Eie
Then Lucio's is. Excellent wretch! with a
Timerous modeſty, ſhe ſtifleth vp
Her v • terance. O ſuch a pregnant Eye!
And yet • ſlow of ſpeech; is a wonder
More d •• ightfull, then any Nature makes.
Haſt thou Lucio, ſo much vnh • ppy witt,
As to be • ealous yet? with thou ſuppoſe
Thy ſelfe ſ • c • re in our diſcou • ſe?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Heauen • orb • d, your Grace ſhould er'e imploy
Your 〈…〉 as to diſcourſe with her
'Till grew 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come hither Lady, come, confeſſe, how chance
Y • u haue b • witch'd my Boy with ſubtill ſmiles,
With wan • on hauiour of thoſe pretty Eies?
Doth H •• uen beſtow ſuch Noble ornaments,
To be abuſed in the vſe: and now
He is your Priſoner too, in cheerefull bonds,
How can you haue the heart to make ſ • ch ſpoile,
And hauock of his beauty? hah! ſpeake Lady!

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I hope your Grace hath thoughts more me • cifull.
I know this match was made in Heauen; and not
Prouok'd by any ſinfull art in me.
How I haue v • 'd him in this little time
That he hath bin my Lord: let him declare.
My duty is ſo ſtrict, I need not bluſh
To heare the ſtory told.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No! looke, looke there. His Eies for very ſhame
Their luſter's loſt are crep't into his head:
Encircled with the weakely cullor blew.
The Roſes in his Cheekes are withered quite
His cleere and briske aſpect is muddy now
And dull: His voyce (that was ſo ſhrill; and could
Euen Trumpet-like, outſcolde the Ecchoe)
Is hollow growne, and horce. Haue you then vs'd him well?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Alas (moſt gracious ſir) goe not about
To make my Lord ſuſpect my Loyalty.
If Nature ſickne in his faculties;
Which (heauen be thanked) I perceiued not yet,
It cannot prooue a guiltineſſe in me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Beleeu't (young wife) I am no Proſelyte,
I ſtill auerr, you are that greedy Nimph,
That hath deuour'd the rich complexion of my Boy.
See how his feature's ſhrunke? his beauty ſtain'd?
The Scythian Dame (whoſe cruelty is ſuch,
Whoſe luſt ſo prodigall, that ſhe doth ſtriue
To kill the able Lecher in the act;
Making her wombe his Sepulchre) would yet
Haue ſpard that wanton handſomeneſſe; to ſhew
As patterne of her Lenitie.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I hope, your Grace will pardon Ignorance,
That ſo ill mannerd is, as not to know
Your meaning.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No matter Lady.
My accuſation ſhall withdraw it ſelfe.
Pretty innocence! Lucio, prepare.
Tis our will to make thy Wife a Courtier;
She ſhall be high in fauour; if ſhe'll leaue
Her modeſty; that's out of faſhion now:
In Neighbour Courts, the Ladys ſo preuaile
With maſculine behauiour: they grow
In factions able to depoſe their Husbands
From the charter of their Sex.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: T'is ſtrange that his diſlike is fled ſo ſoone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your Mariage we wil ſolemnize with maſques,
And Reuels. If Inuention • uer meane,
To get reward for ſubtiltie; tis now.
We take notice (Lucio) She is thy wife,
And thy ſiſter our Foreſte.

sp.speaker: Foreſ. Lucio.
sp.l: We your Graces humbleſt Creatures.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Affection is become a Paraſite;
Striues to pleaſe, whom it cannot benifit.

div.head: Actus Tertius. Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: DORIDO,
sp.l: Knowne, by whom by Citty witts!

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Or my Ladys workemen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who ne're ſaw verſe, but what their Sutors writ,
Which they read like Proſe too.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'le not diſcredit my patience, talke on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They ſay you are particular with a
Great Lady.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Yes, and her Penſioner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Some looſe thing (belike) yet will be at charge,
To ſecure her fame from noyſe. For thou prayſt
Againſt all lechery but thine owne.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And ſhe hath wiſh'd in witty-penitence,
Thou had'ſt beene ſingle in the world,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I, for then ſhe had liu'd chaſte. He growes angry,
His eies looke red.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: No Sir. They bluſh to ſee a Foole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: T'were fit they would imploy their modeſty
At home. For thou art a foole in print.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Yet had he liu'd, when the old Sybill,
Preſented her diuine Manuſcripts, to
The dull Romane; he would haue ſcolded with her,
Vnleſſe his Pamphlets had attain'd the firſt
Acceptance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: True, for euery Poet thinks himſelfe
The beſt Poet in the world.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: And that Satyr not the worſt; wherin
He chides Women, for wearing their Halfe-Ruffes,
Which pinn'd behin'd trans ſc • tuates the face,
Or makes'em looke, like Ianus with two faces.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: A iuſt exception: for going haſtily
To kiſſe his whore; he could not find her Mouth.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Why ſure her breath was ſtrong enough
To direct him to it.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Yet I haue heard nothing, but what deſerues
More pitty, then anger.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: Now when he hath prouided ſome high toy
For the Preſſe; he thinks on d • dic • tion,
Strait chooſeth one of the faction; who muſt
Not Patronize, but buy what he makes vendable,
With praiſe in the Epiſtle.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Can you deny this Couſen Satyriſt?

sp.speaker: Dorid
sp.l: And nothing makes Learning ſo cheape; but that
Euery writer ſells his works.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Nay let's follow; and worry him to peeces.

sp.speaker: Lucio. Foreſte.
sp.l: Our ruine is contriu'd aboue.
If our Maſter p • ocue vnkin'd, the Planets
Gouerne ill: For our gratitude, and care,
Deſerues more conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Foreſte
sp.l: Lookes he ſo ſtrangely on yee?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: As if the obiect were but new to him.
And his owne heart vnſetled in his b •• aſt.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Is his violence ſo ſoone tir'd? ſuruay
The Regiſter of your owne deeds. Speake Sir,
Haue you ſo engroſs'd his eares, as if their
Organ, were yours, not his. Confin'd 'em to
Your owne tongue: and ſo d • priu'd the ſorrowfull,
The grieu'd in heart, of an eaſie audience?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: • euer.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: Since you haue ſhar'd the Dukes prerogatiue,
And by his loue, held oppoſition.
At ſuch great aduantage. did you e're ſlight
With cheape regard, thoſe of high, and Noble birth?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: My ſoule abhorrs ſuch tyranny.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Haue thoſe who weare th'Eternalls Liuery
Bought their wages of ye? Or haue they found
Bold, and skilfull flattery, more helps
Adua • cement; then deepe and modeſt Learning?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Neuer, ſince my diſtinction was of power,
To helpe its choyce.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: In nice triall, or euidence of Law,
Hath Cuſtome (which only giues vs hope
Of certainty in Iuſtice) bin traduc'd
By your obſcure helpe?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Hath the deſolate Wid • ow ſcar'd mercy
From your eies, with her old ruin'd beauty,
(For griefe was neuer amorous) or hath
The torne Begger too ſoone diſmiſſed your charitie
Becauſe not giddy enough to delight
Wantoneſſe.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Then if our great Maſter withdraw his loue;
The weight of ſufferance cannot bruiſe ye;
For the whole world will ſhare i'th burden.

div.stage: Enter a young Gentleman with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: From whom is this ſir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: From my Lord Marquiſe de Loretta.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: I humbly kiſſe his hand.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now luck flatter me but once, and I am made—
Tis ſhort, pray heauen it be ſweete, or I'le nere loue
The Prouerb.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Sir, haue you euer bin in ſeruice,
Vnder any eminent Commander?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Neuer yet.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Reade theſe Foreſte.
How Reputation leſſens in eſteme.
Courteſie growes ſo cheape, that deniall,
Seemes leſſe troubleſome then conſent.
And performance is only Lazy.
The labor of ſubſcription hinders more,
Then thought of that, to which it doth ſubſcribe.
This Letter would faine make you a Captaine
In the new Troupes, ſent to the Valtaline.
But ſure your modeſty will teach you baulke
The graunt, though I ſhould beg ye to receau't.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sir. Shall the grey head, the old Souldier.
That tries misfortune by his conſtancy
Whilſt his blood is frozen into Corrall,
His ſinnes into Wyer: whole Vallor thinkes
To weare Chain'd ſhot, as bracelets on his Loynes.
Shall his preferment be intercepted?
Shall he now traile a Pike vnder a Boy,
Whoſe experience is younger then his face?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: No, the frien • ſhip of the noble Marquiſſe
Shall neuer countenance vniuſt deeds.
Finde a Sute more capable of my grant,
And your acceptance, it is your owne.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Noble Signior, I'le put ye to the teſt.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Princes letters are c • e • per far then thoſe
Which Scriuen • rs put to ſale. If ſuch Pigmyes,
Apes in doublets, procure command oth' Campe,
Let the Cranes wage war agen. No oppoſition
Is too weake to ruinate.—Goe young Lord,
The Duke is ill accompany'd, if on • y
With his owne thoughts. Diſcouer more. Perhaps
His diſcontent concerns not you.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: I feare, yet my hopes would faine comfort me,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I would not be vnmannerly, but if
She be at leaſure, tell her, I am heere.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Pleaſe your Ladyſhip to ſit, Il'e tell her ſo.
She's come already.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I ſaw your entrance. How doe you Siſter?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I humbly thanke your honor, I am well,
Pray diſmiſſe your woman: I would impart
A priuacy.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Watch my Lords comming from the Duke, and bring
Me word, before he is vncoach'd

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O Madam Time is now growne old, and runnes
But ſlowly, I thought each Hower, a yeere,
Vntill I ſaw your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why what's the matter? I hope my brother's well

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Yes, I thanke heauen. But pray come hither.
Who doe you ſuppoſe was with me laſt night,
When my husband was at Court?

sp.speaker: Corſa
sp.l: How ſhould I tell, without you inſtruct me.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Why giue a gueſſe.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: The Lady Benuolia, or the Lady
Vtruvia, who was it?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Nay t'was a Man too.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: That's fine i'faith, pray name him to me.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: What thinke you of the beſt man in Sienna?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: How! was the Duke with ye?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Yes, diſguis'd too: he either came, (or elſe
Pretended ſo) to meete your husband there.
After ſome talke, (in which he did expreſſe
His loue to all our family) he gaue
An ample praiſe of you: and ſayd he ſaw
Already ſo much worth in your faire breaſt
As will adde a knot to your Lords Heart,
And his owne: nay and make his conſtant loue
A patterne for euery royall Maſter.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Indeed, I dayly pray to haue it ſo.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Then he gaue me this ſame Iewell; to you
He recommended the receipt of this.

sp.speaker: Corſa
sp.l: Truſt me wench, they are both full of glory
Rarely cut, and ſet.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Your's is the better of the twaine,

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: It is.
But truely I miſlike the manner of
The gift. Doſt thou thinke his thoughts are honorable?
I prethee tell me?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Th'are ſuch as I ſuſpected at the firſt,
Such as made me to refuſe theſe Iewels.
He ſwore I was a Traytor, if I thought.
He meant amiſſe Or if I did deny
To beare this ſame to you, I did but ill
Require his kind requeſt vnto my husband.
Then in the cloſe he vſd ſuch Art, ſuch ſubtill phraſe,
To free his thoughts from the ſtrict iealouſie
Of mine; as reconcil'd me to obey his will.
You know beſides how harſh it is to chide
With Maieſtie, or ſlight Princes fauors.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I'le ſhew to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I had thought t'haue ſhewne my husband mine too
But ſince t'is capable of curious
Queſtioning, I meane to ſtay awhile.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Thou counſayl'ſt well. Wee'll weare 'em both at once.
Mine is the beſt, I e're was Miſtreſſe of.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: And mine is not ecclipſed much by yours.

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord is neere at hand.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Come Siſter, we ſhall heere the newes at Court.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I'le waite vpon your Ladyſhip.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Caſtruchio, Lothario, Borachio.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Sir Knight, beleeu't Foreſte is the Man▪
That duls your reputation with the Duke.
And ſubbornes the Count againſt ye.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Dares he controle my purpoſes?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Aske honeſt Borachio elſe.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Nay He'le not beleeue me: though I ſhould ſw •••
You ſlout him behind his backe: and when a man
Sees things plainely; he neede not buy ſpectacles,
Till he grow old.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I'le mince the Villaine into ſand, to fill
My Howerglaſſe—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: In this Garden he walkes continually
After dinner. Heere ſtay, and expect him.
And Signior in this skin of parchment; marke
What paines I take, to perfect your reuenge.
I'th' ſhape of tree (which takes roote in Hell)
You ſhall diſcouer all his baſe diſcent.
On that branch appeares a Hangman. Then,
A Iakes-man, then, a Tynker. On's Mothers ſide
A Bawde profeſs'd. then, a Tybb. then a Trypewife.
A Synagogue of Welſh Rabbys; could not
Expreſſe more skill in Genealogies,
Then this includes. Sir, ſhew it him, and he
Inſaniates ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I'le make him weare it on his forehead.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Excellent rage! but not a word of me.
I humbly take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Not the foure winds (met in March) ſhall coole my spleene

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Sir, now we are priuat, tis a fit time
To be troubleſome—

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I'le cram Cerberus, with sopps made of the ſlaues blood—

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Concerning thoſe Offices. I'ue thought on'em.
And will haue 'em all in ſpight of Boltens teeth.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Signior Lothario! Boracho too.
Thou art an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: I, your worſhip is wiſe, to ſpeake no more,
Then what you may well ſtand too.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Baſe ſtemme, deriu'd from I ſope roote,
Our Anceſtors were not ſo familliar.
Behold, & grow more mannerly.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Whats heere? My Pedigree? Some ſawcy knaue
Hath counſell'd him, to this affront. What he,
I muſt know th'originall proiector.
Lay hold vpon thoſe fooles.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Lay hold on me?
Take off your hands; or I will toſſe ye all
Into the cloudes, and kicke the Mountaines after ye.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: I pray bid the Gentleman take good heede;
For my Maſter, can doe all this, and more too
I haue ſeene him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Be you quiet. You that deſire Offices.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: If I doe, what then? there be • hoſe deſire
Worſe things.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Know ye not Rogues, that I can muzle vp
The teſtifie Vnicorne, in a Spinners threed?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Lay all hold on him.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: He that cannot runne for his Liberty
Hath no courage in his Heeles. Let the Goute
Take him, that hath Leggs, and w'ont vſe'em

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: No matter, let him goe. Conuey that foole,
Vnto the Porters Lodge.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: A Chaos ſhall ſucceed this ſame.

sp.speaker: Foreſte.
sp.l: Whither ſo faſt (ſweete Lord!)

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Foreſte, I haue tane my leaue o'th' Duke.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Muſt ye away to night.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Now, preſently. My followers attend
At doore. I onely came to kiſſe thy hands.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: The Sunne will faile yee, ere ye reach Lucca.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: I muſt through. His grace will haue it ſo.
Why doſt thou make thy head, to ſhake and reele,
Vpon thy ſhoulders thus. Is it o'recome
With thoughts, and ſuch as muſt be hid from me?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Take heede, ſuſpition is the Fauorite
Of Time, and Nature, it takes a ſudden grouth:
And gathers in the breſt, like Balls of ſuow,
In ſnow; vntill the weight make it deny
To be remoou'd: then melts at leaſure too.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: He's too moderate, that will at my yeeres,
Be ſatiſfied thus.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Why then conſider thus. You goe to Lucca,
There to congratulate the ſate aproach
Of the Popes Legate; He hath bin there a weeke;
And why he was not viſited ere this
Or why vpon ſuch ſtrict, and ſhort ſummons.
Your ſelfe muſt now be ſent; quite puzles me.
Actions rare, and ſudden, doe commonly
Proceed from fierce neceſsitie: or elſe
From ſome oblique deſigne: which is aſham'd,
To ſhew it ſelfe i'th' publique Rode.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Foreſte is this all?

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: Why me ſweete Patron: this is enough
Of danger, ſince none is merited.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Yong thoughts encourage me to ſufferance.
Each ſtorme is vſher to a gentle calme:
Why toyles with ſpeede, gets ſooneſt home to reſt.
The plodding Mule ſhall ſleepe eternally.
Why ſhould the ſtricken deare bem • ane his death:
His obſequies, were full of noble rites:
Acteons Quire, a iolly Requiem gaue:
And th' Arrow from the bow did ſing his dirge.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Thus thy yeeres doe riddle griefe away;
Making ſorrow ſwift, becauſe 'tis mortall.
Let me waite, on your Lordſhip to your horſe,
And at your better leaſure read this ſame.
I'le tell ye as we goe, who brought it me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: To wrong my boy, vnkinde, inceſtuous heate!
Why is Copulation legal; it giues
Authoritie to luſt, for chaſtetie
Would ſoone conclude the World. O virtuous
Pre • dice, when error, preuents folly!
Fiendes, Deuils, that doe liue in liquid fire,
Haue conſtitutions not halfe ſo hot,
So riotous as mine. But why this?
The beautious Corſa is not yet defil'd.
He that repents e're he commits a fault,
Doth like a thirſty, ſinner ſtore his Soule
With mercy, to abſolue that ſinne himſelfe;
Which he may afterwards, more ſecurely
Fall into. Enough this ſoone Initiates.
The credulous Count her husband, I haue ſent
To Lucca. And tomorrow he returnes.
My plots are limmited too ſhort a time
To become Actions. Nor was it skill
To ſend the Iewell by her ſiſter. Marke!
My Soule and braine, are perfect Courtiers growne;
In my declention, and my greateſt want
They leaue me to inſtruct, and helpe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Theſe fancies are not old: the whole Court
Obſerues him ſtrangely altered. But why
Am I ſent for? that I muſt know, by ſafe,
And cautelous inſinuation.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How ſoone, I'ue profited in diſcipline
Of Hell I muſt through What I did meane
Adultery at firſt; will now I feare
Become a Rape.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Hah! ſtill vpon that ſtring? I like it well,
T'is muſicall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Caſtrucho! art thou come?
Thou haſt bin a Courtier long; but whether
'Twas want of skill in me to chooſe a Man,
Or want of lucke in thee to be my choyce;
Suſpence makes neutrall. But know; my loue
Was tardy, becauſe ſtill voyde of leaſure;
To warrant paſsion well beſtowed; by ſafe
(Though tedious) trials. Affection
That is ſlow, is ſure: And now, I weare my heart
Not in m • ne owne breaſt, but thine.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I haue but one life, it is ſome error
In your Grace, thus t'oblige me to the loſſe
Of more, in your deare ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am not skil'd in words. But I affect
Thy fury. For thou art the bold Satyr,
That whips Foreſte, and the wanton Count,
In thy tart Verſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: My gracious Lord! I ſhall conceiue much griefe,
If my zeale miſtake in accuſation
Of thoſe Men, which th'vncertaine Tongue of Fame
Deliuers to my charge.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay, make not thy confeſsion an excuſe
Rather then a ſtory: For there needs none.
I hate Foreſte, and the Count, and would
Deuiſe ſuccinct ways to my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Heauen forbid: I'de rather farre diſgrace
The skill of my ſubiect; call accuſation
Slander: then that the buſie multitude
Should note inconſtancy in you,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This is a damn'd Hypocrite. Chamellons
Changes, are not ſo intricate to ſenſe.
Caſtruchio! eaſe me with nimble apprehenſion.
I haue not leaſure, to be modeſt now.
Speake; haſt no acquaintance with any neere
Corſa's perſon; the Counts faire wife?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I humbly beg, your Grace would not miſtake
The conditions of my duty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I beg of thee not to miſtake the ſenſe
Of my deſignes. My words import my heart,
And both, no danger vnto thee.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I hope my skill in ſeruitude, will not
Prouoke my Prince to tempt my honor.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What prolixe loue is this; Doſt thou indent
With my acceptance, make choyce of ſeruices!

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Your Grace will giue me leaue; ſince that I know
I not deſerue to ſhare in your high ſecrets,
To doubt my ſafety in knowing this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Death! and horror! thy ſuſpitions are too thinne.
Conſider why I ſent the Count to Lucca?
Vpon my life thou art ſecure: therefore
Reply vnto my former queſtion.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, I haue ſome intereſt
In her woman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In Corſa's woman knowne to thee?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: She is. Perhaps—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Diſcharge thy tongue. May my eares bliſter
If they digeſt words to thy preiudice.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Perhaps I knew her, beyond the modeſt ſtraine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There's Gold. Caſtruchio, ſhew ſome pitty
On rebellious blood. Be my Harbenger,
Billet me this night where ſhe doth lye
And thou art made for euer.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Muſt it be this night?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Strict opportunitie will haue it ſo.
Her Lord returnes with the next Sunne.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I cannot ſay her ſelfe ſhall porter be
Vnto your entrance; but her woman ſhall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Enough! here's more Gold. Smmon vp thy braine
Thy heart, thy ſoule, to meet in conſulation,
And ſo contriue my peace, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I will inſtruct your Grace e're long: both when,
And how to make this armorous aſſault.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My ſelfe and my Exchequer are thine owne.
There needs no Art to worke him into euill;
He is bad enough t'infect the Deuill.

sp.speaker: DORIDO,
sp.l: Good! they haue left the Garden dore vnlocked
I'le venture in to helpe diſcouery.
Caſtruchio is grac'd with rare imployment:
The Duke and he doe heere conſume the Night.
Theſe are houres for Ghoſts, Adulterers
And Theeues. The ſlaue is Haggard. At Supper
Being full of gold: his vaine Appetite
Fed at Nero's rate; I was diſcarded
With a frowne: ſhaken like a Burre from's ſleeue.
As if my cloſure heeretofore had bin
Impertinent. Ambition leſſens all
Beneath it ſelfe to nothing: the higher
We doe ſtand: ſo much leſſe thoſe men appeare
Whom we behold below—Hearke! Kinde Fortune
Lend me thy Eares—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The night growes aged now. T'were fit the Duke
Would haſten his departure. In troth Wench,
Thy ſeruice to him exceeds requitall.
But what; ſhe tooke it willingly!

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: No, but ſhe did not.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Pox 'o theſe modeſt Lies! I ſay ſhe did,

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: In troth you doe abuſe her then; I'm ſure
Her ſhreeks did ſcare my heart vp to my lipps.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Then thou couldſt haue Kiſs'd heartely.

sp.speaker: Duar.
sp.l: I wonder, it wakened not the whole houſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Iſt poſsible! what meanes did the Duke vſe
To ſtifle vp this noyſe?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: Nay, I know not. But ſince ſhe was no more
Pliant; it doth repent me much, I'ere
Was inſtrument to his other actions.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What, repent! I prethee ſweete Duarte
Wrong not Diuinitie ſo much: waſte not
A virtue, that would more profit others:
And to ſuppoſe that the Lady was rauiſh'd,
Is an hereſie, which my Soule muſt nere
Be guilty of. Doe not I know Women
Are a kinde of ſoft waxe, that will receaue
Any impreſsion?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: And doe not I know: there is difference
In workemen as in wax. Hard wax (when cold)
Accepts of no impreſsion. By coldneſſe
I in ferre chaſtitie: for chaſtitie
Is colde,

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But thoſe workemen are harder farre
Then that hard waxe. And t'is hardeſt of all
To finde thoſe workemen: vnleſſe by Ruſsia
Where the people freeze, till they ſpit ſnow. Come,
Kiſſe me Chuck. Agen, once more—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A precious Satyriſt! This ſurly Dog,
Inueyes 'gainſt lechery in others, 'cauſe
He would engroſſe all Women to himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Your greateſt Thieues, are commonly begot
When Parents doe their leachery by ſtealth.
Men get Cowards, when frighted in the Act.
And by ſuch vulgar conſequence: t'is now
A proper time to beget a Pander.
One, that may hereafter doe other men
The ſame office: which we doe the Duke now.
Come. Shall we, in and try?

sp.speaker: Dua.
sp.l: You preſume much, on an eaſie nature;
And how extrauagant you are abroad;
I am not ſo vnkind to queſtion.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Faith Wench: I've ſome intereſt in euery Childe
That playsi'th' ſtreete, The Dukes come down. Go, go,
Giue your Lady a Cawdle: and let me heare
How ſhe likes her new Bedfellow. I'le meete
His Grace two houres hence: when he hath diſmiſs'd
Thoſe thoughts, which ſtill ſucceed vnlawfull luſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O damn'd villany: Is this th'imployment
That doth make ye proude? I will haunt ye ſtill,
To ſtrengthen my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O ſilly, weake euaſion! being darke,
I creepe within my Cloke. T' is modeſty
In ſinne to practiſe euery diſguiſe
To hide it from the World. But Creatures free from guilt
Affect the Sunne, and hate the darke; becauſe
It hides their innocence. O traytour Luſt.
That leades vs with encouragement to fight,
And when we haue diſcharg'd our Vaines for thee,
W'are beſieg'd with thoughts, that more perplex vs
Then the former. For then we did complaine
Of ſtrength; but now of weakneſſe more.
Away, • way. T'is time that I were gone:
The modeſt Morne doth bluſh i'th' Eaſt, as if
Aſham'd to ſee ſo fowle a Rauiſher.

sp.speaker: Dorido.
sp.l: So ſwift of foote! I muſt ouertake ye.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: How now! the World is wide enough: wherefore
Doſt thou ioſtle me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Cry mercy Signior: the day's bleare Eie'd yet,
And my owne haſt made me vnmannerly.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Sig • ior Dorido is it you? Tis much
To ſee you appeare before the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Faith Signior; the Count being out o' Towne

I though •
Foreſte would haue more leaſure
To peruſe my new Sute. He's early vp;
Which caus'd my vigilance.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why Signior vſe a meanes more abſolute;
It is true, Foreſte does all: but how?
As th'inſtrument gouern'd i'th' workemans hand.
Inſtruct me with conueniency of time,
And I will worke the Duke in thy behalfe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then Signior, you will oblige my prayers.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: At ſupper, when you departed from me,
You gaue demonſtrations of diſcontent:
Who knowes, but whilſt the ſoul's imploy'd within;
The body might neglect ſome outward forme,
Which curioſity preferrs to cuſtome.
Cuſtome to abuſe. It was my buſineſſe
Not diſreſpect of you, that did depriue
My complement of vanity. I ſhall
Reioyce when I can ſhew you kindeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Dorid.
sp.l: I will be bold to thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'de haue thee build thy Mansion on a Rocke.
Fauorites are ſeru'd in with thoſe Diſhes
The Prince beſt loues. And meate we moſt affect
We ſooneſt ſurfeit on. Inſtruct thy ſoule.
The Count is but a glorious trifle.
And to be factious without benefit—
Well, thinke vpon't. I know a way to get
The Dukes beſt Eare, without Foreſte's helpe.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The Profit of the day be yours. Theſe tricks
Shall make me weare him in my Eies. The ſlaue
Doth vſher out his breath in ſtate; as if
His honours had out growne his owne knowledge.
Yet but a tame Pande • . The beautious Corſa
Is rauiſh'd by the Duke. O blacke horror.
Ariſe my ſoule, inſpire my induſtry
With noble purpose. Something I'le doe
That ſhall proclaime my Spirit.

sp.speaker: Corsa.
sp.l: Hence, hence, like Time; who ſwiftly flys away,
But euermore returnes. Goe cruell wench!
Thou haſt betray'd thy Miſtreſſe, euen to
Eternall loſſe. Th'Angels that liue aboue
Haue ſeene it all. They know thee well enough.
In the generall Seſsion of the world;
It will not my adultery be call'd;
But a prodigious Rape deriu'd from thee.

sp.speaker: Duarte.
sp.l: Good Madam, your Conſcience is too bold:
It troubles you too much. Diſmiſe't: thinke,
That other Ladys haue offended more.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Out Deuill. Wilt thou betray my ſoule too?
Duarte hence! I am inſpired with ſtrength
To make reuenge prooue maſculine.
Flye quickely hence. Why doeſt thou ſtay? There's Gold.
I prethee wench in all thy Pilgrimage
Diſperſe my faulte in charitable ſence.
Vſe me nobly with thy Tongue. So farewell.

sp.speaker: Duarte.
sp.l: Or let my ſinne no mercy finde in Heauen,
No pitty heere on Earth.

sp.speaker: Corsa.
sp.l: Now all the motiues of my Lords delight
Exterminate for euermore with me.
My ſilent Lute's interred in the Caſe.
My voyce now rather frights, then captiuates
The ſence.
O Siſter, dare you visit me?
I am a ſtrumpet growne. Hence, and ſecure
Your fame.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Alack, what prodegie is this!

sp.speaker: Corsa.
sp.l: I will tell thee all. For I ſhould diſgrace
Iniquitie to be modeſt now. The Duke—

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Ay me! What in that name can priuiledge
Offence?

sp.speaker: Corsa.
sp.l: Heare my Luinna, heare. In midſt of night,
By my pernicious womans helpe; He opes
My chamber doore: whoſe faithfull Hinges ſhreek'd,
To warne me of his dire approach. His Hand
Imployd a Torch, a Torch; whoſe fancy weake
Aged, and blacke, had ouergrowen the flame.
And ſhew'd (me thought) like vnto Tarquins Ghoſt;
Preaching in fire: as if it counſell'd him,
To preuent ſuch pennance by forſaking
His attempt. This, I told him too. But he
(That came not to conſider, but to act)
O're • u • 'd my Hands with his: then made ſhipwrack
Of my Honor.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O royall Villaine!
My ioynts and ſinnews diſsipated are,
And ſcatter'd in a trembling feare. But marke
More ſorrowes yet. My Husband lookeing in
My Cabinet, did ſpy that Iewell there,
Which the Duke laſt gaue me. It was to him
A new, and vnknowne ſtarre: and Commet like,
Imployd his thoughts with ſuch Aſtrologie
As made an Optick of his iealouſie;
Through which, he would diſcerne the cauſe, th' effect
Of its being there. I told him all the truth:
And Truth's oftner prayſed, then rewarded
Heere on Earth: for he diſmiſs'd me ſtreight
With fatall lookes.

sp.speaker: Corsa.
sp.l: My Brother is a noble Gentleman.
Goe, goe, and kneele to him. All iealouſie
Muſt ſtill be ſtrangled in its birth: or Time
Will ſoone conſpire to make it ſtrong enough
To ouercome the truth. Shield vs ſweete Heauen!
The Sybills daunce about my Heart. They lay
Their verges heere: infuſing a prophetique feare:
Which whiſpers we ſhall neuer meete againe,
Lets take a ſolemne leaue—farewell for euer

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Farewell! the noblest Lady o'th' World.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I am glad to ſee thee well Borachio!
But where's thy Maſter? what, in durance ſtill?

sp.speaker: Bora
sp.l: Alas Sir, I (Good Gentleman,) the Roome
Wherein they haue put him, is ſo litle
Hee fills it vp to the Roofe: and is faine
To leaue his Legges Sentinels without doore,
To watch the reſt of his body. Tis no
Chamber, but a Court. Cubbord.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: But they make him amends in his diet.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: They cannot Sir, For he's a fainte eater,
If he would pray ſo often as he faſts;
He had bin at libertie long agoe.
He'le dine vpon a ſingle Pea; and leaue Orts.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Doe they no more regard his potent hopes?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Alas Sir, when Fortune's Tippet ſtands vp,
Few men will lend a pin to tacke it downe,
I, and my linage haue ſweete loſſe of him:
I'm ſure o'that,

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Nay, that's too euident.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: O ſir! I would not a'giuen this Ruſh;
T'haue bin aſſur'd all th'offices in's gift
But hang ſuch Dukes (I ſay) that ſuffer thus
Their Fauorites to be impriſoned.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: How now Borachio! Doſt thou ſpeake treaſon?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Sir, I haue ſayd no more, then what I meane
To vnſay againe: which is but a kinde
