Of looſing one' • labor. An • ' • is better,
To be ill imploy'd then to be idle.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: How the ſlaue ſowes his Prouerbs together.
Are you come? I haue ſtay'd vntill the Clocke
Gaue your promiſe the lye.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: My time was ſpent to more aduantage.
I haue declar'd my intereſt in your blood.
If you aſsiſt my plots; you needs muſt ſhare
Succeſſe, that hath already warranted
A large requitall.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I am reſolu'd: and wiſh my ſelfe more able.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: T'is well. But now you vndertake buſineſſe:
You muſt be as ſerious as a Muſle.
That is: weare your Beard, vpon your tongue: talke,
Brauely. But of all auoyd Dorido
As you would to drinke
A violent poyſon.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Enough, he is a ſtranger to my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: There's freſh encouragement—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: A little more of this mettall would puzle
My Geography; Is this Italy
Or the Indies, There Borachio! Weepe no more
For thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Allas I'm apt to weepe, though I but ſee
An Onyon ſtripp'd naked.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I thought to meete thy Maſter heere. I'm ſure
I ſaw the warrant ſign'd for his releaſe.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: The Deuill take your worſhip for me, why,
D'yee bring ſuch good newes, on a work'y day?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But thou pray'ſt ill, in praying the Deuill
To take me.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Why could he euer come to leſſe purpoſe
Then when he findes you doing well. Though he
Looſe his labour once: I dare warrant ye,
He'le come againe on the ſame arrand.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A bitter foole.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Sir, let we friends be true to one another.
There are but few true friends extant. Let them
Be kindly vs'd and kept, if only for breed.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: With all my heart, tranſlate thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Is my Maſter at liberty?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'le deferre an anſwere of this, vntill
Thy owne Eies be a little elder.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Well, is he ſtill in fauour with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why he ſhall ſhortly gouerne all at Court,
And be a very Mote in the Duk's eye.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Enough. T'is not wholeſome to burſt with • oy.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But what then?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: I'ue thought with much care on theſe Offices:
And finde my ſelfe fitting to be in'em.
I will haue'em all; come Cut, and Long-taile.
For my Wife, will be ſuch a glad woman.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Looke! who comes there?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: O Sir! giue me your bleſsing—

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Weepe not Borachio! I haue prepard
Such bloody art in my reuenge; as makes
Mens wits, more famous then their cruelty,
Let horror propagate. All's too litle
For my vſe. But you Sir had the honor,
To releaſe me.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Or elſe I had bin much dishonor'd.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Sir, now he ſuppoſeth you in durance:
And is himſelfe ſecure; happely drunke,
Or riding in the ſtewes; you may take ſome
Aduantage on his ſoule too. Looſe no time.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: That's my intent.
For it were dull humanitie to aime
No farther then his life. I'le purſue him
Euen to Hell.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: And let me alone ſo to facilitate
The proiect, by ſearch of fit time, and meanes:
As ſhall declare the act leſſe troubleſome,
Then thus to threaten it with words.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: You Signior Caſtruch • o! Signior Coxcombe!
Are you ti • 'd with doing well? you haue ſcarce
Brought my poore Lord out of the Priſon doores;
But you long to haue him in agen. Nay,
N'ere looke! For my Sword dwells within a Yard
Of my Tongue, and ſhall defend what I ſay

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What a p • rnicious Calfe is this?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: What harme haue my poore Wife, and Children done
To you, or yours; that ſeeing me within
A haires breadth, of a hundred offices,
You confound all, by leading my poore Lord
Into new broyles.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Bold Miſcreant! If I but ſtir—

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Nay Signior! let him alone. Borachio!
Steepe thy wrath in cold water: follow,
And be dumbe. All ſhall be well.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Yes, perſwade me to dry Ice in an Ouen!
But I'le follow your Heeles ſo cloſe: as Ile
Goe neere to tread vpon your Kibes.

sp.speaker: Dorido.
sp.l: Signior, I knew ye a braue Commander
Vnder the great Petruchio; and ſince
That time your conſtant virtues haue deſeru'd
More recompence, then Fate will miniſter
By me. My kindeneſſe is no miracle:
Since gratitude is only ſicke, not dead.
But pray beleeue what I haue ſayd is truth.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: O Sir, t'is th'error of vnskilfull loue
To be too conſtant in her charitie
To all. But I haue grounds more relatiue
To make me iealouſe of the truth: and I
Beleeue you with my heart: and yet t'is ſtrange.
Doth this Caſtruchio thinke his haggard fate
Can triumph ouer mine? becauſe in luſt
The Deuill did inſtruct his induſtry:
Dares he attempt my life?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I giue you reall grounds for my ſuſpence.
Reward (ſir) may make a Villaine bloody
Though it cannot make him valiant. The Duke
Will let him want no Gold.

sp.speaker: Fores.
sp.l: Nay t'is often ſeene.
Amongſt the ſeuerall Creatures of a Prince,
Such inſtruments as theſe moſt profit reape.
Imployments noble doe requite themſelues,
And honour payes, the great of heart: who looſe
But Time in ſeruice which is the Bodies wealth.
Your friend ſtays. If you pleaſe t'appeare with him
From thence, at my ſummons: I ſhall diſcouer more.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Noble Signior, I am yours,

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: What hoa? Luinna! Wife!

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Come hither Loue. Signefie in ſecret
When was the royall Lecher heere diſguis'd?
What did he ſend thee laſt? when muſt ye quench
The Cyprian fire: hah! you may tell me all,
For I'le not blabb. Alas, I'm more ſilent
Then my Grandſire in his Tombe. A ſubtill Pimpe, I,
A Pander learned in the art. Tell me Chucke?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Alas my noble Lord! what doe ye meane?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Why nothing, I: yet tis enough I feele
The wrong, If ignorant, I ſuffer twice.
And therefore let me know my Enemy.
The little worme, when trod vpon; will turne
His Head, to looke vpon his Murderer.
And hath my Spleene no Eies: Is the reuenge
Of Man leſſe curious then a Wormes.—She weepes,
O Luinna, the ſacred knot's vnti'd.
Thou haſt defil'd and ſtayn'd the veſtall Sheetes,
Thy Breaſt ſhall be no more my Pillow.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O ſay not ſo. Let Thunder ſtrike me dead,
If I'ere knew the 'Duke; with knowledge more
Diſhoneſt, then what harbours in the Eies;
Only by ſight.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: O new horror! ſuch brazen impudence,
Would make a Negro bluſh. Come glo • ious who • e,
Acquaint me with your tricks. Who! when, where, how •
For beſides the Iewell which he gaue thee:
I haue proofes, that will euen damme my ſiſter;
And conuince thee too.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: My deere Lord? be not cruell in your Faith;
What I haue ſayd is truth.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Still conſtant in thy periurie. Mercy
Were tamen • ſle then. Thou ſhalt dye
Like an heroyique Whore: a 〈◊〉 Martyr
sp.stage: Enter Doride and his Friend in viſards.
sp.l: To thy concealed louer. Appeare ho!
Heere my ſhe goate! Theſe men are full and freſh;
But if they cannot tire ye out: I will
Procure ye ſome of larger Thighs; that feede
On th' vnctious Lhaſis, and the Perſian-Crab.
Or bring the riotous Horſe, and the Towne Bull
To drownd ye in the act. Take her aſide,
And agree who ſhall beginne.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay, O my Husband, my deereſt Lord?
Will you permit ſuch cruelty againſt
Your owne Wife. She, that hath ſo often ſlept
Within your Boſome. O ſpeake? doe you want
The naturall touch • ſtay, ſtay, I will confes't.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: Stay, I'm of too eaſie, too ſoft a Soule.
My Heartſtrings (ſure) are made of ſilke: and 'tis
A ſubtill whore, ſhe knowes it well enough.
But come, be briefe. Charme me not with ſtorys
Of my former loue betweene vs.
I ſee thee as thou art, and thou appear'ſt
Like an intire, proportionable Boyle.
Why ſpeak'ſt thou not?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Sorrow was euer ſlow of v • terance,
And I doe tremble ſtill. I knew the time,
My duty hath bin held in more regard
Then now it is. All former intereſt
Is quit forgot.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Marke, did not I ſuſpect, ſhe would begin
Her Charmes agen. Away with her.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O ſtay, now, now, I will reueale all.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Be nimble then: and tell me punctuall truth,
For my reuenge is honeſt, and would not
Willingly miſtake, when it ſhall ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: T'is true, your Sſter's rauiſh'd by the Duke.
Which fatall truth, this morning I receau'd
From her owne mouth, But if I ere did breake
My Mariage vowes, or thinke vnlawfully;
Then may I looſe my intereſt in Heauen.
My duty, and my loue remaine ſtill yours,
And this conſtancy deſerues ſome kindneſſe.
Therefore, if t'is decreed that I muſt dye:
Let me dye a modeſt death. Expoſe not
Your poore vvife, vnto the cruelty
Of Rauiſhers.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: What thinke ye ſir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My thoughts continue in the former ſence:
I haue a chaſte, and virtuous vvife; howeuer
You deſir'd aſſurance from a triall
So vnkind as this.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Still me thinks that Iewell which he gaue her,
Procur'd the ſame requitall that my Siſter made.
But let it paſſe. I doe coniure ye both,
(As y'haue bin Souldiers) to keepe your Tongues,
A ſafe diſtance from your Eares, Let not words
Diſperſe what you haue heard. T'is externall
Reputation that keepes ſome Men from ſinne.
Our faults once knowne, we doe neglect to mend:
Since Reputation ſuffers ſtill: for that
Admits of helpe, but it is neuer cur'd.
And ſo the fatall iarrs tweene Man, and Wife,
If ſecret kept, diſſenſion falls aſleepe.
But if once knowne to Fame; Fame talks ſo loude
She waketh it agen. Your ſilence Signiors,
Shall challenge much from my requitall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Beſides our obligations to your worth,
Euen both our honors would impoſe it
As a virtue, not a trouble. We are
Your humble ſeruants.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I will deſerue you for my friends. Riſe—
You muſt be cleer'd by a ſtricter triall:
'Till when I doe neglect the large Charter
Of Husbands o're their Wiues: and command ye
As a Iudge th'offendor. Hence, and become
My Priſoner in your Cloſet. Take heede,
No curioſity in feare make you,
To pry in my deſignes.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I doe obay ye cheerefully.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: O my heart! ſhall my induſtry, and hopes
Finde this period? My ſufferance is tir'd.
It is an old inconſtancy in Fate,
Soone to erect, and ſoone to ruinate.

div.head: A Chayre at the Arras. Actus Quintus. Scena Prima.
div.l: FORESTE, No, no, my Starres, it is too much to beare,
Though I were ſtomach'd like an Eſtridge,
Yet could I not digeſt ſuch hard dealing.
My Wife defil'd, Corſa rauiſh'd. The Count
Abus'd where ſatisfaction is exempt
By Nature. My ſelfe proſcrib'd to ſuffer
By the cheape vallour of obſcure Villaines.
Would I had trode the humble path, and made
My induſtry leſſe ambitious. The Shrub
Sccurelie growes. The talleſt Tree, ſtands
Moſt in the winde. And thus we diſtinguiſh
The Noble from the baſe: the Noble finde
Their liues, and deaths ſtill trouble ſome:
But humility doth ſleepe, whilſt the ſtorme
Growes horce with ſcolding My Gall o'reflowes my heart:
And drownes propitious Thoughts. I will be iuſt
Yet cruell too. The darkeneſſe of the Night
Is thicke. I feele as I grope for way—
Stay—That ſickly light from her chamber breaks.
Minion l •• e beginne with you.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Sing gentle youth; who knowes if I ſhall liue
Timploy thy voyce agen.

div.head: Song.
div.l: Boy. Weepe no more for what is paſt
For Time in motion makes ſuch haſt
He hath no leaſure to diſcry
Thoſe errors which he paſſeth by.
If we conſider Accident,
And how repugnant vnto ſence,
It pays deſert with bad euent:
We ſhall diſparedge Prouidence.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: This is your Dirge,

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Hah! who is there?

sp.speaker: Foreſ
sp.l: Tis. I. Diſmiſſe that triſle hence, and ſhut
The doore.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Farewell Youth! Get hee to bed.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: But where's the rigled Hagg; th' inceſtuous lump
Of heate? where is ſhe, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Alas Sir, who doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Fores.
sp.l: Why ſhe that Goſsips with the Deuils Damme,
The ſubtill Bawde, your Woman. O Siſter! Corſa kneeles.
I haue heard all.—Nay doe not worke diſtinction thus.
Kneele not to me; you are my Patrons wife.
But yet where obligation is indeer'd;
There Iniurie condemns it ſelfe. Can you
Surui • e a wrong ſo eminent: a wrong
Committed' gainſt your Husband, and my Patron?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: O Sir! I hope if you haue heard the trueth:
You will conclude it as a rape i'th' Duke;
And no adultery in me.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: How, a rape! o weake, and immodeſt ſhift,
Were Aretine aliue; or had I brought
A Crew of Midwiues heere: whoſe obſcene art
Might warrant the diſtinction good;
Although the cauſe did bluſh, to owne th'effect;
Yet thy appeale might ſtand: but heere are none.
If compulſion doth inſiſt, vntill
Enforcement breed delight, we cannot ſay,
The femall ſuffers. Acceptance at the laſt,
Diſparageth the not conſenting at the firſt:
And not a virtuous froſt i'th' blood.
Come, ſit thee downe.—Or if ye meane to pray,
Kneele, and be nimble in deuotion.
That art to dye.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: My Noble Brother!
Doe not fright my ſufferance: vſe me kindly
With your tongue, and lookes: I am already
Reconcil'd to Heauen; and would perhaps
Conſent to your deſigne.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Bleſſed ſpeech! thou ſhalt preſcribe my geſture
And my Phraſe.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: T'were not vnnaturall in me, to wiſh
For life • yet minding what constructions
The world may make of my ſiniſter chance—

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I there's the point. The giddy multitude
Haue neither skill, nor leaſure to c • nuince
Suppoſition, with Arguments of ſtrength
And charitie. Their quicke cenſure, brings ſuch
Which then • oe rather aggrauate the ſhape:
Then giu • diſtinction of the forme. Who, who,
Would liue to be an Argument for them?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Doe ye conclude then, that I muſt now dye?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Why iſt not apt, and pregnant to your ſence,
It ſhould be ſo?

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Ere I take my laſt leaue of my kinde Lord.

sp.speaker: Fores.
sp.l: Ceremonious forme, doth oft, ſo long
Delay our iourney; till it prooue too late
To reach our home. T'is a long way to Heauen.
We muſt make haſt. Nay, if your courage faile
Before it comes vnto the teſt: I ſhall
Prepare to be vnkind. Grimme, black fancy
Could you indure to ſee your Lord; defil'd,
Polluted as you are? That kinde Patron
To all our family; whoſe conſtant loue
Is warranted by Time; that beſt can iudge
Of conſtancy. Who tooke you to his bed;
Vpon conditions cheape, and dangerous
To his owne eſtate.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Sir, ſpeake no more: but vſe me as you pleaſe;
I will obay in all.

sp.speaker: Fores.
sp.l: Come, ſtretch downe your Arme: and permit this Scarfe
To faſtne it to th' Chaire. Then vaile your Eies.
We muſt not truſt a Woman's vallour ſo—

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Foreſ,
sp.l: The torture's paſt. Thy wriſt waynes are cut, Heere
In this Baſon bleed: till dryneſſe make them curle
Like Lute-ſtrings in the fire—

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Commend me to my deereſt Lord. I am
His humble ſacrifice. Hee'le not be more
Vnwilling to grant attonement: then I
Haue beene to neede it. The Fates giue others
Expiation: which now they want themſelues.
I ſpeake too loude. For who dares chide with them
That may imploy Thunder.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Her beauty'gins to wither. She diſtills
Like to a Roſe. O could I ſeparate
The blood defil'd from what is pure: I would
Shed that; then reſtraine the current, know!
(Vnskilfull Nature) If operation
Should long ſubſiſt in ſuch groſſe mixture: Men,
Would be Deuils 'ere they liu'd in Hell.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I come Celeſtiall Quire!—

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Extaſie! through weakenes in expence of blood!
Deare ſiſter! Diſturbe not your laſt Minutes.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: I muſt aſcend—

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: How! would you enter Heauen; with fetters on
Your Soule? clogg'd with theſe mortall Limbs. Sit downe,
Expire in peace.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: O my Brother! whilſt I am yet humane,
Let me feele ſome intereſt in your blood.
What fault of mine deſerues impediments
In my laſt iourney? If my Lord were heere
He would haue ſeene me vs'd with mercy.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sweete Soule! theſe, are but miſtakes of weakeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Will not my Lord be mercifull; to me,
And to my memory.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sit ſtill. I bring no negatiue reply.
Thy worth ſhall ſhine in ſuch a Character:
That being dead; he needs muſt wooe thy Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: And will Poſterity conſent, that I
Abide in Liſt; with thoſe of modeſt fame?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: That Aſtrologer; who ſpys thee firſt
Within a Starre: muſt not finde thee billeted
Neere to Venus. Such error in his Act;
Would make me wreath his Body into Cords.
And with prolix ſtrength draw the dull Caytiffe,
Through his ſlender Optick.

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: A Convulſion in her Arteries!

sp.speaker: Corſa.
sp.l: Mercy Heauen!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Hearke!
As ſhe aſcends, the Spheares doe welcome her,
With their owne Muſicke.—Her Soule is gone!
Hah? whether is it gone? O vaſt ſuſpence!
Madneſſe ſucceeds inquirie. Fooles of Nature!
What Anceſtor (that dyde long ſince) hath brought
Vs newes of his abode! or told vs how
They vſe him in the other world? O this
Wilde myſterie ſo much concerneth Man:
That we would willingly diſmiſſe ſuſpence
With Eieſight not with conſequence.
For he that ſees through Faith, but flatters doubt.
Faith's a Perſpectiue; through whoſe narrow lane;
Little things (far of) ſeeme ſo much too great,
Too neere: that what was firſt vnknowne is more
Eſtrang'd from knowledge, then it was before.
Yet by the rules of lawfull notion: It
Goes well with her: for ſhe was euer giuen
To prayer: ſuperſtitious in humilitie:
And euen vnthrifty in her charitie.
She held her Virtues in ſuch high extreames,
That her Diuinity was troubleſome.
Grew from a Saint, a holy Cynick. Sleepe heere:
A ſacri • ice to thy wrong'd Lord: Till I
(Thy Pries't) become an Executioner
To him; who was thy cruell Rauiſher.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Doth ſhe inſiſt in cenſure of the act
With ſuch a ſterne impatience, and diſlike?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Euen ſo (Sir) my intelligence imports.
For ſince her Woman, was diſmiſſed: ſhe ſent
A Meſſenger vnto Lucca; to vrge,
Her Lords returne: whom (by a labor'd conſequence)
I doe expect within this Hower. Hee'le chooſe
To trauaile in the Night for priuacie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And I haue ſent to ſtay him there: vntill
A new Commiſsion order his returne.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Moſt royall Sir, you then may gueſſe what frights
Such oppoſition in theſe meſſages
Will nouriſh in his Heart. And being yong,
He cannot feede on doubts. Hee'le rather thinke
His intereſt in you his preuiledge to erre:
So, ſlight your Mandate, and come home,
To ſettle his ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Remorſe doth cheriſh danger! Let me be ſafe,
Sec • re me in thy wholeſome Art. I would
Expreſſe my ſelfe without a Tongue—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: My gracious Lord; my apprehenſion lies
Not in my Eares but in my Braine. I can
Conceiue without the noyſe of words. It ſhewes
Apparent to my intellect: the Count
Preſuming on that free adreſſe, he ſtill
Hath had vnto your perſon: will hither bring Corſa, and Foreſte to ſhew the ſhape,
And quallity, of his new ſufferance.
Be you within your bed, to free you from
The worlds ſuſpition: whilſt I doe place
Behind the Gallery doore (which leads vnto
Your Cloſſet Chappell) ſuch truſty ſpirits,
As ſhall dare to thruſt their weapons home.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O quinteſence of Soule. I will deuote
My actions wholly to thy vſe. Good night.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: May ſlumber ceaze vpon your toyall Eies
With gentle cloſure. Know, poore Foreſte!
The bag that holds my Gall is ſo immenſe,
That when I ſteepe thee in it thou art drownd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Caſtruchio; I haue better thought vpon't.

sp.speaker: Caſt
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would not haue thee hurt my Boy: vſe him
Kindly for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Shall I not ſtrike him heere; betweene the Ribbes?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not for the world. Thou doſt not know his Soule.
He's of ſo ſoft, ſo ſweete a propertie,
That he inchants where he is knowne. Beſides,
I finde I am ſo powerfull o're his youth:
That I ſhall ſoone extirpate from his memory
The wrong I did his Wife, and him. As for
Foreſte: his experience is of growth
Too ſtubborne, of practiſe ſtiffe; and will not
Be remoo'd from his reuenge, by ſtrength of words.
Therefore, let him no mercy feele: but let;
My Boy be gently vs'd for my ſake. Farewell—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: This is a ſilly kinde of loue!
But let me thinke—So to contriue this plot:
That Lothario may deſtroy Foreſte,
And him to make his ſilence ſafe! humh—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No; it muſt not be—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: My royall Lord!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lucio (my Boy) is not proſcrib'd. Take heed
Caſtruchio! If thou doſt extend thy hand:
In motion, boyſterous, and rough to him;
Thou doſt infect all thy other kindneſſe:
And I ſhall ſee thee as a Cocatrice:
That will enforce my Optick-nerues to ſhrinke,
And pull my Eies into my skull. Looke to't.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Moſt gracious Sir, were his perſon bulwark'd
He could not be more ſafe, then you haue made him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Once more then good Night.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A plague vpon this turdy loue. Such thoughts
When firſt your Blood did make your Vaines to ſwell
(Like Bridges'ore your fleſh) had preuented
My imployment. Softely, ſoftely.
Feare, and ſuſpition euer walke on Egges.

div.stage: Enter Foreſte, and Seruants with a Light.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Leaue heere the Light, and goe to Bed.
Breake ope the doore, breake ope the doore.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Hah! who counſels ſo vnlawfully?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: O Foreſte! the fatall Houre is come
Ring out your Bells, vntill they wake the dead.
Let the Drumme murmure in a • able Bagge.
Reuerſe your Muskets, and traile your ſtubborne Pikes
In ſlimy-Channels. Let Trumpets groane,
And the ſhrill Phiph be hoarce. The fatall Hower,
Is come.

sp.speaker: Foreſt.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: O my wife! by this ſhe did entreat me
Suddenly, (vpon ſome vrgent cauſe)
To haſte from Lucca to her: Iuſt now;
I lighted from my Horſe, enter'd her Chamber:
And found her newly murdered in her Chayre.
My Seruants ſay that my arriuall there,
Did iuſt ſucceed your departure from her.

sp.speaker: Fores.
sp.l: Diſmiſſe your Seruants, and you ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Hence, and expect me ſtrait at home.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I pray come hither Sir.—Doe you diſlike

div.l: That iuſtice which depriu'd your Wife of breath?

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: Doeſt thou call it Iuſtice?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Yes, in the nobleſt ſtraine: ſhe was defil'd.
The royall Goate (the Duke) hath rauiſh'd her:
And I (that neuer could admit excuſe
In points of honor) (where euer ſuſpition
Sufficeth to condemne) did ſummon vp
My memory: wherein the kinde effects,
Of your beſt loue to vs are regiſtred.
And finding you betray'd in your owne Fort!
I ſlit her Wriſt- • aynes, and gaue perpetuall
Liberty, to her polluted Blood.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: O Villaine! more bloody then the Tyger;
Whoſe empty Entrailes noyſe, doth (Trumpet like)
Encourage cruelty; Though thou didſt flight her
As my poore Wife: yet ſhe might well expect
Some mercy, as being thy owne ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Had ſhe included all propinquity
Of blood; which lawfull Mariage keepeth knowne,
Or promiscuous Copulation, maketh
Intricate: this bare word (Honor) had bin
Enough, t'haue diuorc'd her from my mercy.
Sweete Lord; doe not miſtake your Seruant:
Whoſe kindeneſſe thinks his owne Siſter (when defil'd)
Was to baſe for your vſe.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: A bloody kindneſſe to diſtinguiſh ſo
She was no Adultereſſe, but enforc'd. Her thoughts
Were pure: and ſuch a noble ſympathy
Indeerd her Soule to mine; that her owne Teares,
Might ſoone haue waſh'd away her Bodys ſtaine,
And ſhe againe ſeeme cleane. Corſa!
O my Wife! my boſome Girle! where art thou?
Speake, no reply? Art thou ſo much buſied
With thy new acquaintance now in Heauen:
That thy poore Lord, may not borrow one word
At parting? Draw, draw ingratefull Monſter!
That haſt preuented thus our Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Sir, coole your ſpleene! take breath awhile:
And heare me ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: No falſe Syren! thou holy Hypocrite!
I know thy tricks too well! 'Cauſe I am yong,
Too ſoft of heart, and apt to melt
In euery flame of my owne triuiall loue;
Therefore thou thinkſt to practiſe on me now
With ſubtill phraſe. Draw, or elſe thou dy'ſt.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Come—Let me dye (as ſhe) a ſacrifice
To thee my Patron.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: A ſacrifice to me! O Foreſte!
Why doſt thou multiply thy skill
To thy friends pr • iudice? It is not well,
In troth it is not. Imploy thy owne heart:
Thinke vpon't thy ſelfe. Tis not kindely done:
I ſhould not haue vs'd you thus—

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: O my deere Lord! where did I looſe your heart?
I am o'recome at theſe expreſsions.
I cannot weepe much: yet my Eies are moyſt.
O my vnskilfull gratitude! what dire
Miſtake, confounds our properties! I kill'd
A Siſter, to ſecure a Friend. T'was ill,
Twas not the right way. A true Romane now,
Would walke aſide, and with his owne Sword
Diſmiſſe his owne Soule: and not permit
Moyſture in youthfull Eies, thus to diſgrace
The ſtrength of elder loue. I cannot weepe,
But our diuinity ſupplyes vs with
Diſcreeter wayes, to make affection knowne;
Enough. I will prefix but one ſhort Houre,
To thinke vpon't. Heere ſir. Sheath your good ſword,
Till reuenge prooue ripe. And I coniure
By all my Siſters loue to follow me:
In whoſe behalfe, your inſtice may imploy
It ſelfe. Which done, you ſhall behold my Heart
Without a Perſpectiue.
If it concerneth her; by whom thou doſt
Coniure my ſeruice, I'm bound to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: What hoa!

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Come Minion, come along with vs. You walke
Vnto the Barte. If triall find thee falſe;
Thou ſhalt be ſcattered into Attomes▪

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O my deuining Soule▪ Sure my Siſter
Is not ſafe.

div.stage: Enter Caſtruchio, Lothario, Coſsimo, ſeuerall wayes.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Signior Lothario!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Heere! Signior Coſsimo!

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I am heere. Speake low. Coſen Caſtruchio.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I am heere too. Why are we ſcattered thus?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: T'is in ſearch of Borachio; who fearing
Danger in this action, commits himſelfe
Very tamely to his Heeles.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Let him be damn'd vnthought of. Haue you heard,
Or ſeene a Paſſenger.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: No, yet Lothario giues me notice:
Of a noyſe farre off: but you know the length
Of an Aſſes eare.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Paſtes there (ſay you) who is't?

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: He ecchoes by miſtake. No body: but
My Couſen ſays he'le lugge the Aſſes eare,
Speaking of your Man.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: The Butchers dog ſhall ſaue him a labor.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, I haue intelligence
(By my Boy) that Foreſte, and the Count,
Are comming hither. Looke to't. But let the Count
Be ſafe. You know his voyce Lothario?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Very diſtinctly.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Well, any Man (but he) that ſtirres his Tongue,
Enuites his owne ruine Giue me your Hands
I'le bring ye to a doore: through which, if they
Doe paſſe, it muſt be ouer vs.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Leaue Foreſte to my charge for I am
His impediment.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Softely, ſoftely.

div.stage: The Duke (on his Bed) is drawne forth. Enter Foreſte, Lucio, Luinna.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Now ſet the reflex at liberty:
Heere let me beg your tariance: 'till I
Reſolue a doubt that moſt concernes my Heart.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: You ſhall. But doe not execute reuenge,
Vpon the Duke; till my aſſent encourage thee.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: My actions are confin'd: Vpon, not in
The Bed? Guilt confounds all order, and makes,
Our reſt vnnaturall. Miſtreſſe, ſtand you there.

div.stage: He leads Her to ſtand at the Beas feete.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hah! from whence that light! who waites within

sp.speaker: Foreſte,
sp.l: is it you? what doe you meane
By this vnciuill viſitation!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I am not ſo vnthrifty of time
To ioyne replys, vnto demands, I muſt
Depriue you of your Soule.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How? Is this Language lawfull, vnto me
Thy Soueraigne Prince. Did not high-prouidence,
Treble the aſſurance of my ſafety:
By Guards inuiſible, when I was firſt
Predeſtinate to this ſupreame function?
And darſt thou tempt the ſtrength of Heauen?

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I know t' were a prophane curioſity
In me, to queſtion the prerogatiues
Of a free Prince. For Ignorance, and a dull,
Eaſie faith; muſt flatter bondage ſtill.
Or Libertie (th'eldeſt Child of Nature)
Confounds predominance, by ſuing for
Equalitie amongſt the Sonnes of Men:
And ſo reuokes a Chaos.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Which ſoone returnes: vnleſſe diſtinction
Perſwade thee fixe my Royalty, aboue
Thy reach: that art my naturall Subiect.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Enough falſe Sir. Warme not the ayre with words.
Be ſtill, or I conclude ye in a trice,
And now requite the Leaſure, I permit
For prayer: by a true reply to what
I ſhall demand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Looke on your oppoſite.
Did you euer make her an Adultereſſe?
Speake truth, ſo come your Soule to Heauen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Neuer. So come my Soule to Heauen, as I
Speake truth.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: O Sir?
Take heede the Periurer hath little hope
On the laſt day, to hide himſelfe i'th' Crowde.
He is a ſinner much too eminent.
But what meant that Iewell which you gaue her;
And which ſhe conceald; till its owne luſture
Did betray it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I gaue it to diſguiſe the cauſe, for which
I ſent the other vnto Corſa.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: That name will prick my fury on: although
I ſtriue to be propitious.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I know Luinna, thou art mercifull:
Forgiue me gentle Girle. It was the firſt
Bargaine we did make i'th' Church, to Share
In ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: And 'tis my duty Sir, to be moſt prompt
In the obſeruance.

sp.speaker: Foreſ,
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: A rude ſummons, that calls me as a Iudge,
To cenſure on the errors of my Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What, Is he there too? O killing obiect!

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Behold (yong Lord) the cruell Rauiſher.
Whom Time himſelfe ſhall neuer parallell,
Though he ſuruay his old Records, and ſcratch
His reuerend Head to waken memory.

sp.speaker: Lucio
sp.l: O horror! furnish vs (ſweet Heauen) with ſome
Inſtinct. Inſpire remorſe: or we accuſe
Thy skilfulneſſe to predeſtine vs a Prince:
Murdring, whom thou didſt annoint our Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: My heart ſwells. I'm full of griefe, and danger.
Some Iron Hoopes to helpe my Ribbes, or I ſhall burſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The cauſe deſerues great alteration.
More then mortallity can ſee, and yet
Be ſafe. I wonder Heauen takes ſo little
Notice of it. I am not ſindg'd to death
With Lightning Like the Dorr: nor murdred through
The Eare with thunder; like a Batt. O Lucio!
Minde not my former loue: but ſtrike, vntill
I groane my laſt.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Foreſte ſheath thy ſword. It muſt not be.
He was our Royall Maſter once, and might
In modeſty compare himſelfe; with all
But Princes; whom Fame reſerues as Paternes,
For my ſake ſheath your Sword.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O I ſhall ſuruiue my Royall Charter!
My creature is more beautifull then I:
More wealthy in his loue.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: For my owne part, I will annihilate
My ſelfe: for ſhould I liue, I ſhould grow madde.
But I am bound to care for you (my Lord)
Take heede! I know the tricks of Maieſtie.
They thinke they cannot be ſecure after
Doing ill; but by doing worſe: that is,
By killing quite, whom erſt they did but wound.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: And that's the ſurgery, which I deſire.
I will endure all. O my Lord, my Lord;
I will not bid Poſterity tell tales: nor charge
Hiſtorians to inſert in Annalls;
On ſuch a Night a great Italian. Duke,
Rauiſh'd his Creature Lucio's Wife: Siſter
To Foreſte, his actiue Councellor.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Lucio, compos'd of ſuch an humble loue:
That to ſecure his Maſters feete, would ſpread.
And ſcatter all his Limmes, for him to walke vpon.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: And Foreſte, whose induſtry, and care
Outwatch'd Leane-vigilance, 'till ſhe grew mad.
But come, Let's leaue him to contriue our deaths.
My Heart ſo fills my mouth, I cannot ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lucio ſtay, Foreſte ſtay awhile.
Leaue me not thus anatomiz'd with breath.
Diſſect me really with your good Swords.
Behold my Breaſt, take out my Heart: and if
You finde your figures there, then vſe my Fame
With Mercy.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Foreſte come away.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Make haſt Luinna.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: I am wak'd out of a ſtrange amazement.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hide me ſwelling Hills! rough, and ſcabbed Rocks,
Ye Quarrles cleaue, and ſucke me in, then ioyne
Againe. Would it not make a Patriarke mad?
O who ſhall bribe the Sunne, that in the day
Of generall accompts: he may auouch
He neuer ſaw me heere. Hah! falſe Memory!
I forgot to tell 'em of Caſtruchio.
Tis beſt to o'retake 'em. I cannot gueſſe
Which way they went.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Hell, and the Pillary take ſuch dull Eares.
It cannot be, but they haue paſs'd the Cloyſters,
And e're this, with helpe of priuate Keyes,
Entred the Dukes Bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Thoſe were Authors of that noyſe, I ſpoke of.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The very ſame. A pox vpon demurres.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: Will you lead the way, that we may hearken
If they be there, or no.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If I ſhould come too late?—

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: That's none of the Counts voyce. Haue at ye ſir;

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, O, O, I am ſurpriz'd in my owne ſnare.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: It is Foreſte ſure. Let's make ſafe worke
Kill Lothario, lay him by him, and depart,

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: O Villaines, O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: What noyſe is that?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Another Foreſte.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: My Royall Maſter bleeding on the Ground:
O murderous Villaines:

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Murder, murder. Helpe! oh helpe?

div.stage: Lucio fights with Coſsimo, Foreſte with Caſtruchio.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: The Duke my Soueraign • ſla • e, and Lucio
Bleeding at his feete. Villaine take this thruſt
At my owne preiudice.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: I am foyld by a baſe hand.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Flie Coſime, flie.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Some comfort yet remaines: in that I am,
Proſcrib'd to ſhare in thy fate, though it be bad.
I looſe much blood. O triuiall fortitude,
Falſe Sinnewes, doe you begin to ſhrinke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lucio, Let my Soule, cary your pardon
With her vnto Heauen; and yours Foreſte.
This ſtrangeme was mine, but the ſucceſſe,
Was much againſt my will.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Sir, I forgiue you all.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: Nay let vs ioyne Hands.—We doe forgiue
Each other, and the World. The like mercy
May Heauen beſtow on vs.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: There his heartſtrings broke. Lucio (my Patron)
Already Chapf • lne to: that ſight deſerues a Teare:
Though I ſhould ſtabb my Eies to warrant it.

div.stage: Enter Dorido, Luinna, Courtiers with Light: Caſtruchio: and Coſimo: led in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Bring the ſlaues in, their deeds will ſoone conuince
Their faint deniall, where did you leaue 'em Lady?

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: Here, here, O my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Foreſ.
sp.l: I haue not breath enough to comfort thee.
With words, mercy Heauen.

sp.speaker: Luin.
sp.l: O my Lord? my Husband He's dead, he's dead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hold the Lady there: O dire ſpectacle.
the Duke, Lucio, Foreſte, and Lothario
Lye here breathleſſe. I did ſuſpect ſome blacke
Conſpiracy. Which made me haunt them two
Vnto the Pallace, but I did looſe 'em
By the Chappell ſtaires; bloody dogs, what Deuill
Prompted thee to this action.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I hope, I'ue not ſo much Blood left, as will preſerue
Me for an anſweere.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: I feele my end to neere.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Take em away, and cloſe their wounds, though there
Be ſome mercy ſhewne, by thus deferring
That reward which your blacke ſoules ſhall receaue
In Hell. Yet know the Law will heere on Earth
Prouide ſuch tortures as ſhall make your deaths
Exemplary to all ſucceeding times.—
sp.stage: exeunt ſome with Caſt. and Coſ.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your ſilence may be excus'd.
Where, theres ſo much cauſe of admiration.
Some helpe transfer the dead from hence, others
Call vp the Councellors of ſtate.
So intricate is Heauens reuenge gainſt luſt.
The righteous ſuffer here, with the vniuſt.
